 'Yes, it definitely is a lot to take in. Cali, do you want to talk about what it was like when your parents were arguing? Was that something that happened often?'
 "Yeah, it happened all the time. They would argue about little things and then it would escalate into a big fight. Sometimes they would yell at each other and say mean things. It was really uncomfortable for me to be around because I didn't know how to handle it."
 'That sounds very difficult for you to witness on a regular basis. How did you cope with seeing your parents argue so much?'
 'Well, sometimes I would try and distract myself by playing video games or watching TV, but it was hard because I could still hear them fighting even if I wasn\'t in the same room as them. Other times, I would just go outside and try and get away from the house until they calmed down."']

head: PersonX receives counseling
literal: Radley receives counseling because Radley wants to feel better.
narrative: Radley has been feeling down lately and decided to seek out counseling. Radley went online and found a therapist that specializes in helping people with depression. Radley made an appointment and is looking forward to feeling better soon.
dialogue:
["Hi, therapist. I'm not sure where to start, but I guess I've been feeling really down lately. It's like everything in my life is just gray and bleak. I don't enjoy anything anymore and it's just really hard to motivate myself to do anything. Do you think you could help me?"
 'Of course, Radley. Depression is a very common issue that people seek counseling for. I would be more than happy to help you work through whatever is going on in your life that has you feeling this way. Can you tell me a little bit more about what has been going on? What seems to be the problem?'
 "It's just like...I don't know. Everything is such a hassle. I used to love going out and hanging with my friends but now it feels like more trouble than it's worth. I don't have any energy for anything and I'm just really struggling to get through each day."
 "It sounds like you're feeling pretty hopeless right now. Have you been having thoughts of harming yourself or anyone else?"
 "No, nothing like that. I would never do anything like that. I'm just really down and frustrated with how my life is going."
 "Okay, that's good to hear. suicidal thoughts are something we need to take very seriously, so I'm glad to hear that's not something you're experiencing right now. Can you tell me more about why you feel like everything is such a hassle? What specifically has been bothering you?"
 "I don't know...it's just everything. School, work, my personal life...nothing seems to be going right lately. And even when things are going well, I just can't seem to enjoy it because I'm so bogged down by all the other stuff that's stressing me out."
 "It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed by everything in your life right now. That can be a very difficult place to be in and can definitely contribute to feeling depressed. Are there any particular areas of your life that seem to be causing the most stress? If we could focus on those and try to make some changes, it might help you feel better overall."
 'Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It\'s just...I don\'t know where to start, you know? Everything feels so daunting and insurmountable right now. But if we could focus on one thing at a time, maybe that would help me feel better."']

head: PersonX receives counseling
literal: Arnulfo had a problem. Arnulfo receives counseling.
narrative: Arnulfo had a problem with her mental health. Arnulfo was struggling with depression and anxiety, so she decided to seek counseling from a professional. After meeting with her counselor and discussing her symptoms, Arnulfo felt better equipped to manage her mental health and improve her overall wellbeing.
dialogue:
["So, I guess the first thing I wanted to talk about is just how I've been feeling lately. It's been really tough and I just feel like I'm not myself."
 'What specifically has been tough for you? Can you give me some examples?'
 "Well, lately I've just been feeling really down and hopeless. Everything feels like such a struggle and I don't know how to make it better. I've been having a lot of negative thoughts and it's just hard to shake them off. And on top of that, my anxiety has been through the roof. I'm constantly on edge and feeling like something bad is going to happen. It's just really hard to cope with everything."
 "I'm sorry to hear that you're going through all of this. It sounds like it's been a really tough time for you. But it sounds like you're doing your best to manage everything, which is commendable. Can you tell me more about these negative thoughts you've been having? What do they say specifically?"
 "They just tell me that I'm not good enough, that I'll never be able to improve my situation. They tell me that I'm worthless and that nobody cares about me. And lately, it's just been really hard to push those thoughts away."
 "It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of negative self-talk. That can be tough to deal with, but it's important to remember that those thoughts are not necessarily true. Just because you have those thoughts doesn't mean they're accurate representations of reality. Can you think of any evidence that disproves those negative thoughts?"
 "Well, my friends and family have always been there for me and they care about me a lot. And I know that I've achieved things in the past despite feeling like this, so I know it's possible to overcome these feelings."
 "Exactly. Just because you're feeling down doesn't mean you can't still achieve great things. It sounds like you have a lot of people in your life who care about you, which is really positive. Have you been reaching out to them for support?"
 "Yeah, I've been trying to talk to them more lately and lean on them when I'm feeling down. It definitely helps to know that they're there for me no matter what."
 "That's good to hear. It sounds like you're surrounded by people who love and support you, which is really important during tough times like this."]

head: PersonX finds hope and self-esteem in counseling
literal: Reanna finds hope and self-esteem in counseling. Now Reanna wants to be happy.
narrative: Reanna was struggling in school and felt like she wasn't good enough. She started going to counseling and found hope and self-esteem. Now Reanna is happy and feels like she can accomplish anything.
dialogue:
["I just feel so lost and helpless. I don't know what to do."
 "It sounds like you're feeling really down about yourself right now. Can you tell me more about why you feel that way?"
 "I just feel like I'm not good enough. No matter what I do, it's never enough. And everyone else seems to be doing better than me. I just feel so behind and like I can't catch up."
 "It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure and comparison to others right now. That can be really tough to deal with. But it's important to remember that everyone is on their own journey in life and we all have different strengths and weaknesses. Just because someone else may seem to be doing better than you doesn't mean that they actually are. Everyone has struggles that they're dealing with, even if it doesn't seem like it on the outside. So try not to compare yourself too much to others because it's not an accurate measure of where you're at in life or how successful you are."
 "Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It's just hard when I see other people doing well and achieving things while I'm still struggling with the same things."
 "Yes, it can be difficult when we compare ourselves to others but it's important to remember that everyone is on their own journey in life and we all have different strengths and weaknesses.. Just because someone else may seem to be doing better than you doesn't mean they actually are..Everyone has struggles they're dealing with, even if it doesn't seem like it on the outside.. So try not focus too much on what others are doing or achieving instead focus more on your own progress"
 "Alright, I'll try to do that. Thanks for talking with me."
 'Of course, anytime.']

head: PersonX is given counseling

Through her counselor's guidance, Chanda learns how to cope with her emotions in a healthier way and becomes motivated to make positive changes in her life.
dialogue:
['Hey, thanks for seeing me again.' 'Of course. How are you doing?'
 "I'm feeling a little better, I think. But I'm still really ashamed of what I did."
 "Chanda, there's no need to be ashamed. You made a mistake, but that doesn't mean you're a bad person. We all make mistakes. What's important is that you're here, trying to make things right."
 "Yeah, I know. It's just hard sometimes. I feel like I'm never going to be good enough."
 "Chanda, that's not true at all. You are capable of change and you are doing the work to make those changes happen. That takes courage and strength. Be proud of yourself for that."
 'Thank you. I needed to hear that.'
 "You're welcome. How are things going with your plan to change your behavior?"
 "It's going okay, I guess. Some days are better than others. But I'm still trying and that's what matters, right?"
 "Absolutely. Rome wasn't built in a day and neither is recovery. Just keep taking it one day at a time and don't be too hard on yourself if you have a setback. We all have them. The important thing is to get back up and keep going."
 'Yeah, I know. Thanks for being here for me, it really means a lot.'
 'Anytime, Chanda.']

head: PersonX enters counseling
literal: Emile is helpful. Emile enters counseling.
narrative: Emile always goes out of her way to help others, so when she found out about the free counseling services at her school, she decided to give it a try. After her first session, Emile felt like a weight had been lifted off of her shoulders and she began to look forward to her weekly visits.
dialogue:
["Hey, thanks for seeing me today. I'm really not sure what to talk about, but I guess I've been feeling kind of down lately."
 "That's perfectly understandable. Why don't you tell me a little bit about what's been going on?"
 "Well, I guess things have just been really tough lately. My parents are getting divorced, and it's just been really hard to deal with. On top of that, I've been having some problems with my friends. It feels like they're always excluding me and talking about me behind my back. It just sucks feeling like I'm the one always left out."
 "It sounds like you're carrying a lot of hurt and resentment right now. That can be tough to deal with, but it sounds like you're handling it all very well considering how much is going on in your life. Have you talked to your friends about how you're feeling? They might not even realize that they're hurting your feelings."
 "No, I haven't said anything to them yet...I don't know if it would even make a difference. They seem so happy without me anyway."
 "Well, it definitely couldn't hurt to try talking to them about how you feel. They might be more understanding than you think and maybe even apologize for unintentionally hurting your feelings"
 "Yeah, I guess you're right. It's worth a shot, right? Thanks for talking with me today. I feel a little better already."
 "You're welcome, Emile. I'm here for you anytime you need to talk."]

head: PersonX is given counseling
literal: Isacc is given counseling. Now Isacc feels helped.
narrative: Isacc is given counseling. The counselor helps Isacc to feel better by talking to him about his problems and helping him to find solutions. Isacc feels helped by the counseling and is grateful for the help he has received.
dialogue:
["Thank you so much for seeing me, counselor. I've been feeling really down lately and I'm not sure what to do."
 "That's perfectly normal, Isacc. A lot of people feel like that at some point in their lives. Can you tell me what's been going on?"
 "Well, my mom died a few months ago and it's just been really hard. I miss her so much and I don't know how to deal with it. On top of that, my dad has been drinking a lot lately and he's just not the same person. I'm worried about him but I don't know how to help him either. It feels like everything is falling apart."
 "I'm so sorry to hear that, Isacc. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot right now. Grief can be very difficult to deal with, especially when we feel like we have no control over it. But it is possible to get through this with time and support. As for your dad, it sounds like you're really worried about him but you're not sure how to help him because you're dealing with your own grief too. That's a lot for anyone to handle but you are not alone in this Isacc. We can work together to figure out some solutions for both of your situations if you're willing to talk about them?"
 "Yeah, I'd like that. Thank you."
 "Okay, let's start with your mom. How are you feeling about her death?"
 "I feel so lost without her. She was my everything and now she's gone. I didn't even get to say goodbye to her."
 "That sounds very painful and confusing. It's natural for you to feel like that after such a loss. Can you tell me more about your relationship with your mom?"
 "We were really close. She was always there for me, no matter what. I could tell her anything and she would always know how to make me feel better. Now that she's gone, I don't know who to turn to when I need someone to talk to."
 "It sounds like you miss having that close relationship with her but it's also understandable that you would be feeling confused and alone right now without her in your life. Have you been talking to anyone else about how you're feeling?"
 "No, not really. My dad is dealing with his own grief so I don't want to burden him with my problems too. And my friends just don't understand what I'm going through so it's hard to talk to them about it as well."
 'It\'s perfectly normal for you not want to burden your dad with your problems right now but it sounds like it might be helpful for you to talk to someone who does understand what you\'re going through - which is why counseling can be so helpful Isacc. Here we can talk about anything that\'s on your mind in a safe and confidential space without judgement or pressure from anyone else."']

head: PersonX needs counseling
literal: Alvin needs counseling. Now Alvin feels upset.
narrative: Alvin feels upset because they are struggling in school and feel like they are not good enough. They feel like they need counseling to help them improve their grades and self-esteem.
dialogue:
["I just feel so down lately. I'm struggling in school and I feel like I'm not good enough."
 "It sounds like you're feeling pretty frustrated with yourself right now. Can you tell me more about why you think you're not good enough?"
 "I just can't seem to get my grades up no matter how hard I try. And everyone else seems to be doing better than me. It feels like I'm just not cut out for this."
 "Well, first of all, it's important to remember that everyone learns at their own pace and that comparison is often counterproductive. Secondly, your grades are not necessarily indicative of your intelligence or worth as a person. They can be improved with hard work and dedication."
 "But it feels like I've been trying so hard and it's just not enough. I don't know what else to do."
 "It sounds like you're feeling really stuck right now. Have you considered seeking out tutoring or academic support? Sometimes having some extra help can make all the difference."
 "Yeah, maybe that could help...I don't know, I just feel so down about all of this right now. Counseling seems like such a big step...I don't know if I'm ready for that yet."
 "Well, that's understandable. Counseling can be a big commitment. But it can also be incredibly helpful in situations like this. It sounds like you're really struggling right now and could benefit from some professional support."
 "I guess...I'm just not sure if I'm ready to take that step yet."
 "That's okay, there's no pressure to make a decision right now. Just know that we're here for you when you're ready."]

head: PersonX insists on a divorce
tail: to get rid of his wife
literal: Kelley insists on a divorce because Kelley wants to get rid of his wife.
narrative: Kelley and her husband have been having difficulty communicating lately, so she suggested marriage counseling. After several sessions, it was clear that their relationship was beyond repair. Kelley asked for a divorce, and her husband agreed.
dialogue:
['I think we both know that our relationship is beyond repair.'
 "I suppose you're right."
 "I've been thinking about this for a long time, and I think it's time for us to get a divorce."
 "I agree. I think it's for the best."
 "It's not going to be easy, but I think we can get through this if we're honest with each other and communicate well."
 'That sounds like a good plan.']

head: PersonX refuses to go for counseling
literal: Goldy refuses to go for counseling because Goldy wants to avoid the therapy.
narrative: Goldy avoids counseling because she does not want to talk about her problems with a therapist. She would rather keep her issues to herself and deal with them on her own.
dialogue:
["I'm really not comfortable talking about my personal issues with a stranger."
 "I understand that you may feel uncomfortable discussing your problems with someone you don't know, but it's important to remember that therapist-client confidentiality is very important. Anything you say in here stays between us."
 "I'm still not sure if I'm ready to talk about everything."
 "That's perfectly understandable. Sometimes it takes a little while to build up trust with your therapist. Why don't we start by talking about why you came to see me today?"
 "I guess I just wanted someone to talk to about my problems. I'm really struggling right now and I don't feel like I have anyone to talk to."
 "That sounds very difficult. Can you tell me more about what's going on?"
 "I don't know, it's just everything. My job, my relationship, my friends, it all feels like it's falling apart and I don't know what to do."
 "It sounds like you're feeling very overwhelmed and hopeless right now. Have you been having any suicidal thoughts?"
 "Yes, lately I've been thinking about killing myself a lot. But I would never actually do it, I'm just so tired of feeling this way all the time."
 "It's understandable that you would be feeling that way given everything that's going on in your life, but it's important for you to know that there are other options besides suicide. We can work together to help you find other ways to cope with your pain."]

head: PersonX refuses to go for counseling
literal: Khori refuses to go for counseling because Khori wants to stay in denial.
narrative: Khori is in denial about her husband's affair and refuses to go to counseling. She wants to pretend like it never happened and act like everything is normal. Her husband has been trying to get her to go to counseling with him, but she always refuses.
dialogue:
["I don't want to go to counseling. It's like admitting that something is wrong, and I'm not ready to do that yet. I know you had an affair, but I refuse to believe that it means anything. It was just a one-time thing and it doesn't have to change anything between us."
 "Khori, we can't pretend like this never happened. It's going to take some time to heal, but we need to deal with it in a healthy way. Counseling can help us do that."
 "I don't see how talking about our problems is going to help anything. We should just move on and forget it ever happened. That's the best way to deal with it, in my opinion."
 "Khori, if we don't talk about what happened, then we'll never be able to move on from it. Ignoring the problem won't make it go away. In fact, it will probably make things worse in the long run."
 "I don't want to talk about it. It's over and done with, and that's the way I want to keep it. Let's just move on and forget it ever happened."
 "Khori, we can't ignore what happened. It's going to take some time to heal, but we need to deal with it in a healthy way. Counseling can help us do that."]

head: PersonX undergoes something
literal: Bradley undergoes something because Bradley wants to be a better person.
narrative: Bradley wants to be a better person, so they undergo counseling. Through counseling, Bradley is able to talk about their experiences and figure out ways to improve their life.
dialogue:
["I really appreciate you seeing me, counselor. I know I've been through a lot and I need to figure out how to be a better person."
 "I'm glad you came in, Bradley. Let's talk about what's been going on in your life. You said you want to be a better person. What do you mean by that?"
 'I mean that I want to improve myself in every way possible. I want to be happier, healthier, and more successful. And I know that counseling can help me get there.'
 "That's great! So, where would you like to start?"
 'Well, I guess we can start with my childhood. I had a really tough time growing up. My parents were always fighting and I never felt like I fit in.'
 'That sounds difficult. How did that make you feel?'
 'It made me feel really alone and like there was something wrong with me. I was always trying to figure out what I could do to make my parents happy, but it never seemed to work.'
 'That must have been really hard for you. Can you tell me more about how that affected your life?'
 'It made me not want to get close to people because I was afraid they would leave me too. And it also made me really angry all the time. I used to lash out at people and get into fights a lot.'
 "So, you've struggled with anger issues in the past?"
 "Yeah, definitely. It's something that I've been working on for a long time now. But it's still something that I struggle with sometimes."
 "What do you do when you're feeling angry?"
 "Well, nowadays, I try to take some deep breaths and count to 10 before doing anything else. That usually helps calm me down enough so that I don't do or say anything rash. But sometimes it doesn't work and I still end up getting angry anyway."
 "That's understandable. Anger is a normal emotion and it's okay to feel it from time to time. Just be careful not to let it take over your life or lead to negative behaviors like violence or verbal abuse"]

head: PersonX hears a counselor on the radio
tail: to be able to talk to someone
literal: Tony hears a counselor on the radio because Tony wants to be able to talk to someone.
narrative: Tony turns on the radio and hears a counselor talking about how to deal with stress. Tony is interested in what the counselor has to say and decides to call the counseling center.
dialogue:
['Hello?' 'Hi, Tony. How are you doing today?'
 "I'm doing alright, I guess. I just heard your show on the radio and thought I could use some advice."
 "Sure, what's going on?"
 "Well, lately I've been feeling really stressed out. Everything seems to be getting on top of me and I don't know how to deal with it all. Do you have any advice?"
 'Absolutely. Stress is a very common issue that people face. It\'s important to understand that stress is a normal part of life and it\'s not something that you can eliminate completely. However, there are things that you can do to manage your stress in a healthy way. For example, one thing you can do is to make sure that you\'re taking care of yourself physically by eating healthy and getting enough exercise. Additionally, it\'s important to take some time for yourself every day to relax and do something that you enjoy. This could be reading, listening to music, or spending time with friends or family. Finally, it\'s also helpful to talk about your stress with someone who will understand and can offer support. If you\'re feeling like your stress is becoming too much to handle, please don\'t hesitate to reach out for help from a professional counselor or therapist."'
 "Thank you, that was really helpful. I'm going to try to take your advice and see if it makes a difference."
 "I'm glad to hear that, Tony. If you ever need to talk again, please don't hesitate to call back or come in for a visit."]

head: PersonX begins a counseling session
tail: learns to deal with his anger
literal: Layah begins a counseling session. Now Layah learns to deal with his anger.
narrative: Layah is a young woman who is struggling to deal with her anger. In her counseling session, she begins to learn how to better cope with her emotions. She talks about her triggers and what makes her angry, and she starts to develop a plan for how to deal with her anger in a more constructive way.
dialogue:
["I don't know, it just seems like lately I can't help but get angry over everything. Everything just sets me off and I can't control it."
 'What do you think is causing this increase in anger?'
 "I don't know. It's just everything, like I said. Everything bothers me and makes me mad."
 'Is there anything in particular that seems to trigger your anger?'
 'Yeah, there are definitely certain things that will set me off more than others. For example, if someone cuts me off in traffic or if someone is being really loud and obnoxious, those things will definitely make me angrier than other things. But really, anything can set me off at this point.'
 "So it sounds like you're feeling a lot of frustration and annoyance in your day-to-day life. Is that accurate?"
 "Yes, that's definitely accurate. I'm just so frustrated all the time and I don't know how to deal with it constructively. Nothing seems to be going my way lately and it's really taking a toll on me emotionally."
 "Well, let's talk about some ways that you can deal with your anger constructively rather than letting it build up inside of you until it explodes. What do you think would work for you?"
 "Well, I guess first of all, I need to be more aware of when I'm getting angry so that I can try to stop myself before it gets too bad. Secondly, once I am aware that I'm getting angry, I need to take some deep breaths and try to calm myself down before doing or saying anything rash. And finally, even after I've calmed down, if the thing that made me angry is still bothering me, then maybe talking about it calmly with the person who upset me or with somebody else who was involved in the situation could help diffuse the anger even further."
 "Those are all great suggestions! Let's try implementing them the next time you start to feel yourself getting angry and see how they work for you."]

head: PersonX meets a counselor
literal: Makaylee meets a counselor. Now Makaylee wants to go to counseling.
narrative: Makaylee had been struggling with his mental health for a while when he finally decided to seek help from a counselor. After just one session, Makaylee felt relief and hope for the first time in months. He left the office feeling motivated to continue counseling and improve his mental health.
dialogue:
["I'm really glad I decided to come here today. I feel like I finally have some hope for the first time in a long time."
 "I'm glad to hear that, Makaylee. Can you tell me what's been going on that's been causing you so much distress?"
 "It's just been hard lately. I've been feeling really down and helpless and like nothing is ever going to get better."
 "That sounds very difficult. But it sounds like you're starting to see that things can improve with counseling."
 "Yeah, I am. I think part of what has helped is just finally talking to someone about everything that's going on. It feels good to be heard and understood."
 "Absolutely. That's a big part of what counseling can offer- a safe place to share your thoughts and feelings without judgement or criticism. Just being able to talk openly about what's going on can be very helpful in itself."
 'Yeah, I definitely feel like it has been. Just having that outlet to talk about everything has made a big difference.'
 "I'm glad to hear that. Are there any other things that you feel have been helpful in your session today?"
 "I think just the fact that you were really listening and didn't try to fix everything or tell me what to do. It was really refreshing to just be heard without judgement."
 "That's great feedback, thank you. I think it's important for people to feel like they can be themselves without feeling like they need to put on a front or pretend to be someone they're not. So hearing that you felt comfortable being yourself with me is very gratifying."
 'Yeah, it definitely makes me want to come back and continue counseling. I think it could really help me in the long run.'
 "That's great news, Makaylee! I'm so glad you're feeling hopeful and motivated to continue counseling."]

head: PersonX avoids a counseling referral
literal: Bryson avoids a counseling referral because Bryson wants to avoid therapy.
narrative: Bryson avoids a counseling referral because Bryson is avoiding therapy. Bryson is avoiding therapy because of the stigma that surrounds it and because she doesn't want to face her problems.
dialogue:
["I don't think I need therapy." 'Why not?'
 "I don't know...it just seems like a lot of work and I'm not sure it would even help."
 "Well, it can't hurt to try, right?" 'I guess not...'
 "And if you're really not comfortable with the idea of therapy, maybe you could just talk to me about stuff? I'm a good listener."
 'Yeah...I might take you up on that. Thanks, Cristina.']

head: PersonX receives counseling
literal: Dayra receives counseling because Dayra wants to improve his relationships.
narrative: Dayra is in counseling because he feels like he has been struggling in his relationships with others. He wants to learn how to communicate better and understand what might be causing some of the conflict.
dialogue:
["It feels like I can't ever say the right thing. I'll try to have a conversation with someone, and it just ends up in a fight. I don't know how to make friends or keep them."
 "It sounds like you feel like you're struggling in your relationships with others. Can you tell me more about that? What do you think might be causing some of the conflict?"
 "I don't know. It just seems like no matter what I say, it always ends up wrong somehow. I must be doing something wrong, but I don't know what it is. Maybe there's something wrong with me that makes people not want to be around me."
 "That's a possibility, but we won't know for sure until we explore it further. Let's talk about some of your specific relationships that have been causing you difficulty. Can you give me an example?"
 "Well, there's my family. We're always fighting about something or other. And my friends from school…I used to have a lot of them, but now it feels like they're all drifting away and I don't know why."
 "It sounds like you're feeling really alone right now. Have there been any changes in your life recently that might have contributed to this feeling?"
 "I don't know. Everything just feels so different lately. My dad lost his job, and we're struggling to make ends meet. That's been hard on all of us. And then my best friend moved away, and it feels like everyone else is changing too."
 "It sounds like you've experienced a lot of loss recently. That can be really tough to deal with. Let's talk about how you're coping with all of these changes. Have you been talking to anyone about how you're feeling?"]

head: PersonX hears a counselor on the radio
literal: Aleah hears a counselor on the radio. Now Aleah seeks counseling.
narrative: Aleah heard a counselor on the radio talking about helping people who are struggling with anxiety and she decided that she would seek counseling herself. She made an appointment with the counselor and went in for her first session. After talking to the counselor, Aleah felt better understanding her anxiety and had some tools to help deal with it.
dialogue:
['Hi, thanks for seeing me.' 'Of course, how are you doing today?'
 "I'm feeling a little anxious, but I'm glad to be here."
 "That's perfectly normal. Can you tell me more about what's going on?"
 "Well, I've been feeling really anxious lately and I'm not sure why. I just feel like something bad is going to happen."
 'Do you have any specific worries or concerns?'
 "I guess I'm just worried about everything in general. I don't know what's going to happen in the future and it's scary."
 "It sounds like you're experiencing some anxiety about change. Change can be hard to deal with, but it's a natural part of life."
 "Yeah, I know it is, but that doesn't make it any easier."
 "No, it doesn't. But there are ways to deal with anxiety and make it more manageable. For example, have you tried relaxation techniques or exercise?"
 "Yes, I've tried both of those things and they do help a little bit. But the anxiety always comes back eventually."
 "That's understandable. It takes time to learn how to manage anxiety and there will be setbacks along the way. But as long as you keep working at it, you'll get there eventually"]

head: PersonX agrees to seeing a counselor
literal: Johana agrees to seeing a counselor because Johana wants to get help.
narrative: Johana is willing to see a counselor because she knows she needs help. She has been struggling for a while and feels like she's at her wit's end. Counseling could give her the tools she needs to cope with her stressors in a healthy way.
dialogue:
["Hi, counselor. I'm really struggling and I feel like I need help."
 "Thank you for coming in, Johana. Can you tell me what's going on?"
 "I've just been really stressed lately. I have a lot going on in my life and I feel like I can't cope with it all. Everything feels like it's piling up on me and I can't handle it anymore. I'm just so tired all the time and I don't know what to do."
 "It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and hopeless. That can be really tough to deal with. Let's talk about some of the things that are stressing you out. Maybe we can brainstorm some ways to help you cope with them better."
 "Well, one of the big things is my job. I work in customer service and it's just so stressful. I deal with angry customers all day and it's really taking a toll on me. I feel like I'm just constantly yelling at people and I hate it."
 'It sounds like your job is really affecting your mental state. Have you considered looking for a new job?'
 "Yeah, I've been thinking about it but I'm not sure what else I would do. I need something that pays well and customer service is the only thing I've ever done."
 "That's understandable. It can be hard to make a career change, but sometimes it's necessary for our mental health. Let's brainstorm some other options for you. What are some other things you're interested in?"
 "I don't know...I've always liked working with kids so maybe something in that field?"
 "That's definitely a possibility! There are lots of jobs working with children that could be less stressful than customer service. Do you have any experience working with kids?"
 "No, not really...I used to babysit when I was younger but that's about it."
 "That's okay! There are plenty of entry-level jobs in childcare that don't require much experience. Let's look into some of those options and see if any of them seem like a good fit for you."]

head: PersonX gets in trouble again
literal: Sheila is rebellious. Sheila gets in trouble again.
narrative: Sheila gets in trouble again. This time she was caught smoking cigarettes behind the school. The principal gave her a choice, either she could be expelled or attend counseling.
dialogue:
["I don't see why I have to be here. I'm not the one with the problem."
 "Sheila, you were caught smoking cigarettes behind the school. That's a serious offense. If you're expelled, it will go on your record and follow you for the rest of your life."
 "So what? It's not like I'm going to college or anything."
 "Even if you're not planning on going to college, a criminal record can still make it difficult to get a job later on down the road. Not to mention, it would be a real shame to throw away your future over something like this."
 "I don't care about my future. What's the point? Everything sucks anyways."
 "Sheila, life isn't always easy, but that doesn't mean it's not worth living. You have so much potential and I would hate to see you throw it all away because you're feeling angry or frustrated right now. There's help available if you're willing to accept it."
 "I don't need help. I can handle things on my own."
 "Sheila, you're only sixteen. You're not supposed to have everything figured out yet. That's what we're here for, to help guide you through these tough times."
 "I don't want your help. I can do this on my own."
 "Okay, Sheila, if that's how you feel then there's not much more we can do here. But I want you to know that we're here for you if you ever change your mind and decide that you need our help."]

head: PersonX wants to start anew
literal: Araceli is courageous. Araceli wants to start anew.
narrative: Araceli was sitting in her car, parked outside of her soon-to-be ex-husband's house. She had just left their final counseling session, and she was feeling both scared and hopeful. She was scared about what the future would hold, but hopeful that she could start anew.
dialogue:
["I'm not sure what the future holds, but I'm hopeful that I can start anew. I feel like I've been holding my breath for so long, just waiting for things to end. And now that they are, I feel like I can finally breathe again. It's going to be scary, starting over on my own, but I'm ready for it."
 "Starting over can be scary, but it can also be really exciting. It's a chance to create your own life, on your own terms. You don't have to do things the way anyone else wants you to anymore. You can make all the decisions and build something that feels right for you."
 "It does feel kind of liberating, doesn't it? Like I finally have control over my own life again. After being in a relationship where everything was decided for me, it's nice to be able to make my own choices again. But at the same time, it's also scary because now all of the responsibility is on me. If things go wrong, there's no one else to blame but myself."
 "But that's also a good thing! You're taking control of your life and you're accountable for your own happiness now. That's a really empowering feeling once you get used to it. So yes, it might be scary at first, but ultimately it'll be worth it because you'll be living your life exactly how you want to live it!"
 "I'm starting to see that. And I think you're right, it is empowering. I feel like I can finally start living my life the way I want to live it, instead of the way someone else wants me to live it. So thank you, Nicole, for being here for me and for helping me see things in a new light."
 "Of course! That's what friends are for!"]

head: PersonX feels misunderstood
literal: Akilah feels misunderstood. Now Akilah decides to seek counseling.
narrative: Akilah has been feeling misunderstood by his friends and family lately. He's decided to seek counseling in order to help him communicate better with the people in his life.
dialogue:
["I just feel like nobody really gets me. My family, my friends...they all just see the world differently than I do. And I don't know how to make them understand me."
 "It sounds like you're feeling very misunderstood. Can you tell me more about that? What specifically makes you feel this way?"
 'Well, it\'s like...I\'ll give you an example. Recently, one of my friends said something that really hurt my feelings. And when I tried to talk to her about it, she just didn\'t get it. She was like, "I was just joking! Why are you getting so upset?" And I was like, "Because what you said wasn\'t funny to me." But she just couldn\'t understand why I felt that way. It was frustrating.'
 "I see. So it sounds like you feel like your friend wasn't able to empathize with how you were feeling."
 "Yeah, exactly. And it's not just that one instance, either. I feel like this happens a lot with the people in my life. They just don't seem to get how I'm feeling or why I'm feeling that way. And it makes me feel alone and lost and frustrated."
 "Akilah, it sounds like you're struggling with communication in your relationships. Do you want to talk about some strategies for how to better communicate with the people in your life?"]

head: PersonX considers developing a system
literal: Joslynn considers developing a system. Now Joslynn feels motivated.
narrative: Joslynn considers developing a system to help people with their careers. Joslynn creates a questionnaire to help people assess their skills and interests. Joslynn offers career counseling services to help people choose the right career path.
dialogue:
["Hi, thanks for coming in to see me. I'm excited to help you figure out what career path would be the best fit for you."
 "To get started, I've developed a questionnaire that will help assess your skills and interests. After we go over your answers, we can discuss some career options that might be a good fit for you. Sound good?"
 'Sure, that sounds fine.'
 "Great. So, let's get started with the questions. Do you have any experience in customer service?"
 "Yes, I've worked in customer service for about 4 years."
 'Excellent. Customer service is a great skillset to have. What do you enjoy most about it?'
 'I like helping people and solving problems.'
 "That's terrific. Those are both qualities that are essential for success in any career. Are you interested in pursuing a career in customer service?"
 "Yes, I think so. I'm not sure what else I would be interested in doing."
 "Well, let's explore some other options then and see if anything else interests you. Do you have any experience with computers?"]

head: PersonX enters counseling
literal: Rory enters counseling because Rory wants to improve her life.
narrative: Rory has been feeling down and wants to improve her life, so she enters counseling. She meets with a counselor weekly and discusses her struggles and goals. Through counseling, Rory begins to feel better about herself and makes progress towards her goals.
dialogue:
["I just feel like I'm not good enough. No matter what I do, it's never enough."
 "It sounds like you're really hard on yourself. Do you think that might be part of the problem?"
 'Yeah, I guess so. I just feel like I can never measure up.'
 "So it sounds like you're constantly comparing yourself to others and coming up short. Is that accurate?"
 'Yeah, pretty much. I see other people and they seem to have their act together and be successful and happy, and I just feel like a failure in comparison.'
 "That's a very common feeling, but it's important to remember that everyone has their own struggles and journey in life. Just because someone else appears to have things together doesn't mean they don't have their own issues going on beneath the surface. So instead of comparing yourself to others, focus on your own progress and journey. How far have you come? What are some accomplishments or positive changes you've made in your life? Celebrate those things instead of fixating on what you perceive as someone else's success."
 "Yeah, that makes sense. I guess I've been so focused on what everyone else has that I haven't taken the time to appreciate my own accomplishments."
 "Exactly. So why don't we take a few minutes and brainstorm some of your accomplishments?"]

head: PersonX is very troubled
literal: Dawson is very troubled. Now Dawson seeks counseling.
narrative: Dawson is a young woman who is struggling with her mental health. She has been seeking counseling for some time now in order to help her deal with her problems. Dawson is currently dealing with depression and anxiety, and she hopes that with the help of her counselor she will be able to overcome these issues.
dialogue:
['Hey.' 'Hi, Dawson. How are you today?'
 "I'm feeling pretty down today. I just can't seem to shake this feeling of sadness and anxiety."
 "That sounds really tough. Can you tell me more about what's going on?"
 "It's just been really hard lately. I feel like I'm not good enough and that everyone is always judging me. I don't know how to make it stop."
 "It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure from yourself and from others. Can you talk more about that? What specifically are you worried about?"
 "I don't know...I guess I'm just worried that I'm not good enough and that people are always going to be disappointed in me. No matter what I do, it feels like it's never enough. And I hate myself for it."
 "Dawson, it sounds like you're really hard on yourself and that you have a lot of self-doubt. These are common feelings for someone struggling with depression or anxiety, but it doesn't mean that they're true thoughts. Can we work on challenging some of these negative thoughts together?"
 'Yeah, I think that would be helpful.'
 "Great. So, let's start with the thought that you're not good enough. What evidence do you have to support that?"
 "I don't know...I guess it just feels like no matter what I do, it's never good enough."
 "Okay. So it sounds like you're basing this thought on your past experiences where you may have not met your own expectations or someone else's expectations. But just because something didn't go the way you wanted in the past doesn't mean it will always be that way. Do you agree?"
 "Yeah, I guess you're right."
 'Okay. So let\'s try to come up with a more balanced thought about this situation. Instead of thinking "I\'m not good enough," how about "I\'m doing my best and that\'s all that matters." Does that feel better to think?'
 'Yeah, it does actually. Thank you.']

head: PersonX avoids a counseling referral
tail: to be free of the therapy
literal: Hadleigh avoids a counseling referral because Hadleigh wants to be free of the therapy.
narrative: Hadleigh refuses to go to counseling because she doesn't want to relive her trauma. She would rather keep her pain bottled up inside, where it can't hurt anyone but herself.
dialogue:
["I don't want to go to counseling. I don't want to talk about what happened. It's too painful."
 "Hadleigh, you need to process what happened. It's not healthy to keep everything bottled up inside."
 "I know, but I can't deal with it right now. I just want to forget it ever happened."
 "That's not going to help you in the long run. You need to face your fears and talk about what happened. Otherwise, you're just going to keep reliving it over and over again in your head."
 'I can\'t do that, Sarah. I\'m sorry, but I just can\'t."']

head: PersonX begins a counseling session
literal: Joanne is sensitive. Joanne begins a counseling session.
narrative: Joanne is a twenty-year-old college student who is seeking counseling for anxiety and depression. She describes herself as being very sensitive, and says that she often feels overwhelmed by her emotions. Joanne hopes to learn how to better cope with her anxiety and depression in counseling.
dialogue:
["I'm just really struggling right now. I feel like I can't handle my emotions and they're just constantly overwhelming me."
 "That sounds very difficult. Can you tell me more about how you're feeling?"
 "I just feel so sensitive all the time. Everything feels like it's just too much for me and I can't cope with it. It's like my emotions are constantly running wild and I can't control them."
 'That does sound very tough to deal with. Have you been experiencing this for a while?'
 "Yeah, it's been going on for a few months now. It's just gotten progressively worse over time."
 "Okay, well let's talk about some ways that we can help you to better cope with your anxiety and depression. First of all, have you been doing any self-care lately? This is always a good place to start when trying to improve your mental health. Self-care can be anything from getting enough sleep, to eating healthy foods, to spending time outside in nature. Just anything that helps you to relax and take care of yourself both physically and emotionally. What are some things that you typically do for self-care?"
 "Well, I try to exercise regularly and eat healthy most of the time. But lately, even those things haven't been helping as much as they used to. I'm just finding it hard to do anything that makes me feel better these days."
 'Okay, well let\'s brainstorm some other self-care ideas then that might help you to feel better both physically and emotionally. For example, maybe there is something that you enjoy doing such as reading or listening to music that you could make more time for in your life right now? Or maybe there is a place that makes you feel calm and safe such as the beach or the mountains where you could go for a walk or spend some time outdoors? Just thinking of things that might help you relax both mentally and physically can be helpful in brainstorming self-care ideas."'
 'Yeah, that makes sense. I think I need to find something that can help me relax mentally more than anything. Just something to take my mind off of things for a little while.'
 'Okay, well let\'s brainstorm some ideas then. Maybe you could try reading fiction books or listening to calming music? Or maybe there is a hobby that you enjoy doing such as painting or hiking that you could make more time for in your life? Just thinking of things that might help you relax both mentally and physically can be helpful in brainstorming self-care ideas."']

head: PersonX begins a counseling session
tail: is better able to cope with his problems
literal: Ainslee begins a counseling session. Now Ainslee is better able to cope with his problems.
narrative: Ainslee begins a counseling session. The counselor asks Ainslee how he is feeling and why he is there. Ainslee tells the counselor that he has been feeling down and anxious lately, and that he wants to get some help to cope with his problems.
dialogue:
["I don't really know where to start. I guess I've just been feeling down and anxious a lot lately. It's been hard to focus on anything or enjoy anything."
 "That sounds tough. Can you tell me more about why you're feeling this way?"
 "Well, I'm going through some major changes in my life right now. My parents are getting divorced, and I'm having to switch schools. It's all just been really overwhelming and stressful."
 'That definitely sounds like a lot to deal with. How have you been coping with all of these changes?'
 "Not very well, to be honest. I've been trying to keep busy and distract myself, but it's not really helping. I just feel so lost and alone right now."
 "It sounds like you're feeling pretty overwhelmed by everything that's going on in your life right now. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling?"
 "No, not really. I don't want to burden anyone else with my problems, and I'm afraid they won't understand or be able to help me anyway."
 "Well, it's good that you came here today then. We can talk about whatever is on your mind and try to figure out some ways for you to cope with all of this change in your life."]

head: PersonX goes back to counseling
literal: Siddharth is open-minded. Siddharth goes back to counseling.
narrative: Siddharth is willing to consider other points of view and try new things. After some reflection, Siddharth decides to give counseling another chance. Siddharth Schedules an appointment with his counselor from high school and they begin meeting weekly to discuss the progress he's made.
dialogue:
['Hey, how are you?' "I'm good, Siddharth. How are you?"
 "I'm good. I've been thinking about what you said and I'm willing to give counseling another chance."
 "That's great, Siddharth. I'm glad to hear that. What made you change your mind?"
 "Well, I realized that I was being too closed-minded and that there might be some benefits to counseling after all. Plus, it can't hurt to talk to someone who's impartial and objective, right?"
 "That's right. So what would you like to talk about today?"
 "I don't know. I guess we can start with why I came to counseling in the first place."
 'Okay. So you were having some difficulties in high school?'
 "Yeah. It was tough for me, especially after my parents got divorced. I felt like I didn't have anyone to talk to or confide in."
 'How did that make you feel?'
 'Well, at first it was really hard. I felt like I was all alone and that no one understood me. But eventually I started to realize that there were other people who had been through similar experiences, and that made me feel a little better.'
 'It sounds like it took you a while to adjust to your new reality.'
 'Yeah, it did. But slowly but surely, things started to get better and I began to feel more like myself again.'
 "That's great, Siddharth! It sounds like you've come a long way since then. Are there any other issues that you'd like to talk about today?"
 'Not really, just wanted to update you on how things are going lately."']

head: PersonX attempts to get help
literal: Traci attempts to get help. Now Traci receives counseling.
narrative: Traci attempts to get help by seeking counseling from a mental health professional. She finds relief and healing in talking about her struggles and feels more hopeful for the future.
dialogue:
["I'm really struggling right now and I'm not sure what to do."
 "It sounds like you're feeling lost and hopeless. Can you tell me more about what's going on?"
 "I just feel like I can't do anything right. No matter what I do, it feels like it's not good enough. I know my family loves me, but I feel like they'd be better off without me."
 "Traci, it sounds like you're experiencing a lot of self-doubt and negative self-talk. These are common symptoms of depression and anxiety. It's important to remember that your thoughts are not necessarily accurate or true. Just because you think something doesn't make it so."
 "But it feels so real to me. Like there's this voice in my head telling me I'm worthless and that everyone would be better off without me."
 "Yes, those voices can be very convincing, but we need to remember that they're just thoughts, not reality. Depression and anxiety can distort our thinking and make us believe things that aren't true. That's why it's so important to get help from a professional who can help you learn how to manage your thoughts and feelings in a more healthy way."
 "I guess I never really thought of it that way. It makes sense that my thoughts wouldn't be accurate if I'm feeling so down all the time."
 "Exactly. Just because you're thinking something doesn't make it true. That's why it's so important to get help from a professional who can help you learn how to manage your thoughts and feelings in a more healthy way."]

head: PersonX finds hope and self-esteem in counseling
literal: Tristen finds hope and self-esteem in counseling. Now Tristen wants to become a counselor.
narrative: Tristen finds hope and self-esteem in counseling. Now Tristen wants to become a counselor so that he can help others who may be struggling with similar issues. Tristen is passionate about helping others and feels that this is his calling in life.
dialogue:
['Hey, thanks for seeing me today.' 'Of course, how are you doing?'
 "I'm doing alright. Just been feeling a little down lately."
 "That's completely understandable. What's been going on that's been causing you to feel this way?"
 "Well, I've just been feeling really alone and like nobody understands me. My family doesn't get me and my friends are all busy with their own lives. I just feel like I'm stuck in this rut and I don't know how to get out of it."
 "Tristen, it sounds like you're feeling really lost right now. But I want you to know that you're not alone. We're here to talk through whatever is going on and figure out a plan to help you feel better. You deserve to feel happy and supported, and we're going to do everything we can to help you get there."
 "Thank you. Just knowing that I'm not alone in this really helps."
 "Absolutely. So, let's talk about some of the things you can do to start feeling better. Have you been doing any self-care lately?"
 "To be honest, I haven't really been taking care of myself at all. I've been skipping meals, not working out, and just vegging out in front of the TV."
 "That's understandable given how you're feeling, but it's important to make sure you're taking care of yourself physically and emotionally. Can we brainstorm some ideas of things you can do to take care of yourself?"
 'Yeah, that sounds good.'
 "Great. Let's start with physical self-care. What are some things you enjoy doing that make you feel good physically?"
 'I like going for walks, lifting weights, and playing basketball.'
 'Those are all great activities! How often have you been doing them lately?'
 'Not as much as I used to...I guess maybe once or twice a week at most.'
 "Okay, let's try to increase that to three or four times a week. As for emotional self-care, what are some things that help you relax and de-stress?"
 "Honestly, just talking to someone who understands me really helps. That's why I'm here today actually. Just having someone to talk to makes me feel so much better already."
 "That's great! We'll definitely continue to talk as often as we need to, but is there anyone else in your life that you can talk to about how you're feeling? A friend or family member perhaps?"
 "I don't really have anyone in my life right now that I feel comfortable talking to about this stuff...but maybe after our sessions together I'll feel more confident reaching out to people close to me about how I'm feeling."]

head: PersonX goes to a crisis center
literal: Mckenzie goes to a crisis center. Now Mckenzie receives counseling.
narrative: Mckenzie goes to a crisis center for help. They offer counseling and Mckenzie decides to try it. After a few sessions, Mckenzie feels better and is able to cope with their problem.
dialogue:
['Hey, thanks for seeing me.' 'Of course. How are you doing?'
 "I've been better. Just feeling really down lately."
 "That's understandable. What's been going on?"
 "Just feeling really hopeless and helpless. Like there's nothing I can do to make things better."
 'That sounds very difficult. Can you tell me more about that?'
 "It's just, everything feels so pointless. Why bother getting out of bed in the morning when nothing good is going to happen? And then when something bad does happen, it just feels like confirmation that life sucks and there's no point to anything. I don't know, it all just feels so overwhelming sometimes."
 "Yes, it sounds like you're feeling really stuck right now. But it doesn't have to be this way forever. We can work together to help you find some hope and meaning again in your life. Would you be willing to give that a try?"
 'Yeah, I think I would like that.' "Great. Let's get started then."]

head: PersonX enters counseling
literal: Haylea had a problem. Haylea enters counseling.
narrative: Haylea had a problem with depression and anxiety. She went to counseling to learn how to deal with her condition and improve her mental health.
dialogue:
['Hey, thanks for seeing me today.' 'Of course. How are you feeling?'
 "I'm feeling really down lately. I'm just struggling to keep up with everything and I feel like I'm falling behind."
 "That sounds tough. Can you tell me more about what's going on?"
 "It's just been really hard lately. I've been having a lot of anxiety and my depression has been acting up. I don't know how to deal with it all and it's just really overwhelming."
 "That definitely sounds like a lot to handle. Let's see if we can work on some coping skills to help you deal with everything that's going on. Do you think that would be helpful?"]

head: PersonX has terrible problems
literal: Connor has terrible problems. Now Connor wants to get help.
narrative: Connor is having a lot of trouble in her life and she wants to get some help. She is struggling with her mental health, her relationships, and her finances. She has decided to seek out therapy and counseling in order to help herself get back on track.
dialogue:
["I'm really struggling right now. I don't know how to fix things."
 'What specifically are you struggling with?'
 "My mental health, my relationships, and my finances. I just feel like I'm spinning my wheels and getting nowhere."
 'That sounds very difficult. How long have you been feeling this way?'
 "It's been building for a while, but it feels like it's all come to a head in the past few months. I just don't know what to do anymore."
 'Have you considered seeking therapy or counseling?'
 "Yes, that's why I'm here. I want to try and get some help so that I can get back on track."
 "That's a great idea. Let's talk about your mental health first. How have you been feeling lately?"
 "Honestly, I've been feeling really down. I'm struggling to concentrate or get motivated. I just feel like I'm stuck in this rut and I can't get out."
 'That sounds very difficult. Have you been experiencing any other symptoms?'
 "Yes, I've been having a lot of intrusive thoughts and my anxiety has been through the roof. I'm also not sleeping well, which is making everything worse."
 "That definitely sounds like something we need to work on. Let's talk about your relationships next. How have things been going with your family and friends?"
 "Not great. My parents are really supportive, but they don't understand what I'm going through. And my friends...I don't know if they're really my friends anymore. We just don't have anything in common anymore and it feels like they're always judging me."
 "That sounds very lonely and isolating. Let's talk about your finances next. Are you able to keep up with your bills and expenses?"
 "Barely. I'm constantly worrying about money and whether or not I'll be able to make ends meet each month. It's just a lot of stress that I can't seem to shake off no matter what I do."
 'That definitely sounds like something we need to work on together']

head: PersonX really appreciates seeing a counselor
literal: Harlee really appreciates seeing a counselor. Now Harlee wants to be in counseling.
narrative: Harlee had been dealing with a lot of stress from school and her personal life, so she decided to see a counselor. Harlee found that talking to someone who was unbiased and could offer helpful advice was really beneficial for her. Now, Harlee looks forward to her weekly counseling sessions as a time to reflect on her week and work through any issues she's been having.
dialogue:
['Hey, thanks for seeing me again.'
 "Of course, what's been going on since we last talked?"
 "Just the usual stress from school and my personal life. I've been feeling really overwhelmed lately."
 "That sounds tough. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?"
 "Yeah, I've just been having a lot of trouble balancing everything. My classes are really demanding and I'm also dealing with some stuff at home. I feel like I'm constantly juggling everything and I'm just not sure how to keep everything together."
 "That definitely sounds like a lot to handle. Let's talk about some of the things you're doing to manage your stress levels. Are you still using deep breathing exercises when you start to feel overwhelmed?"
 "Yeah, that definitely helps me calm down in the moment, but it doesn't really fix the root of the problem. I still feel like I'm just barely managing everything and it's all going to come crashing down on me eventually."
 "That's a valid concern. It sounds like you're feeling pretty helpless right now. Harlee, one of the things we've talked about in previous sessions is developing a support system to help you through tough times like this. Have you reached out to any friends or family members for help?"
 "No, not yet…I guess I'm just worried that they'll think I can't handle things or that I'm being too much of a burden."
 "Those are valid concerns, but it's important to remember that your friends and family care about you and want to help if they can. Why don't we brainstorm some people who might be able to offer support during this difficult time?"]

head: PersonX and PersonY check themselves into a rehab center
literal: Riki and Ryker check themselves into a rehab center. Now Riki and Ryker stay clean.
narrative: Riki and Ryker check themselves into a rehab center in order to stay clean. The two work hard on their sobriety, attending meetings and counseling sessions. They eventually succeed in staying sober, and credit the rehab center for helping them turn their lives around.
dialogue:
['Hey, Ryker.' 'Hey, Riki. How are you doing?'
 "I'm doing alright. Just attending a lot of meetings and counseling sessions."
 "Yeah, me too. I'm glad we're both here and working on our sobriety."
 "Yeah, it's definitely been a challenge but I'm feeling good about it."
 "That's great! I'm really proud of you, man."
 "Thanks, Ryker. I couldn't have done it without your support."
 "Of course! We're in this together!"]

head: PersonX agrees to seeing a counselor
literal: Audrina agrees to seeing a counselor. Now Audrina feels relieved.
narrative: Audrina knows that she needs help and decides to seek counseling. She makes an appointment with a therapist and feels much better after talking about her problems.
dialogue:
["Hi, I'm Audrina. I'm here to see the therapist."
 "Hello, Audrina. Please have a seat and we'll get started. So, what brings you in today?"
 "Well, I've been feeling really down lately and I just can't seem to snap out of it. Everything feels hopeless and I don't know who to talk to about it. I thought maybe counseling could help me sort things out."
 "I see. Well, Audrina, we'll do our best to help you through whatever is troubling you. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?"
 "It's just, ever since my dad died, I've felt like I'm just going through the motions of life. I don't feel like I'm really living anymore. I know it's been a few years, but it feels like yesterday sometimes. I miss him so much."
 "Yes, it sounds like you're still grieving his loss. That can be very difficult to deal with. Have you been doing anything to help cope with your grief?"
 "Yeah, I've been going to therapy for a while now and that's helped some. But lately, I just feel like I'm stuck in this dark place and I can't seem to find my way out."
 "It sounds like you're feeling very lost and alone right now. That's understandable given what you're going through. Grief can be a very isolating experience. Have you been reaching out to family and friends for support?"
 "Yeah, but it's hard because they're all dealing with their own stuff too and they can't really relate to what I'm going through. Sometimes I feel like they just want me to get over it already and move on with my life."
 "That must be really tough for you to deal with. It sounds like you need some understanding and support that maybe your family and friends can't give right now. Maybe we can work on that in counseling?"
 "Yeah, that would be great actually. Just knowing that somebody understands what I'm going through would mean a lot to me right now"]

head: PersonX receives counseling
literal: Ivon receives counseling. Now Ivon becomes more empathetic.
narrative: Ivon receives counseling for her depression. Through therapy, she becomes more aware of the feelings and needs of others. She learns to be more compassionate and understanding, and as a result, her relationships improve.
dialogue:
["I'm really struggling lately. I just can't seem to make myself happy no matter what I do."
 "It sounds like you're feeling pretty hopeless right now. What's been going on that's been causing you so much pain?"
 "It's just everything. My job, my relationships, nothing feels good anymore. I used to be able to find joy in things, but now it all seems pointless."
 "You sound like you're in a really dark place right now. But I want you to know that there is hope and we can work together to help you find your way back to the light. Let's talk about some of the specific things that have been bothering you. What's been going on at work?"
 "Work has just been really stressful lately. I feel like I'm never doing enough, no matter how hard I try. And my boss is always on my case about something or other. It feels like everything I do is wrong."
 "That sounds very difficult to deal with on a daily basis. No wonder you're feeling so down about everything if work is such a source of stress for you. Let's talk about your relationships too. How are things going with your friends and family?"
 "Not great either, actually...I've been having some disagreements with my friends lately and it's really strained those relationships. And as for family, well...my parents are getting divorced, so that's not exactly easy to deal with either!"
 'Yeah, that definitely sounds like a lot to deal with all at once! No wonder you\'re feeling overwhelmed and depressed. But it sounds like you\'re handling all of this incredibly well considering how much stress you\'re under."'
 "Thank you, I appreciate that. It's just really hard sometimes, feeling like I can't make things better no matter how hard I try."
 "Yes, I can imagine that would be incredibly frustrating and discouraging. But remember, you're not alone in this. We're here to help you every step of the way. Just take it one day at a time and trust that things will eventually get better."]

head: PersonX works for the NGO
literal: Ryleigh works for the NGO. Now Ryleigh becomes a social worker.

dialogue:
['Hi, how are you doing today?'
 "I'm doing alright, I guess. Just struggling to get by."
 "Yeah, I can understand that. It's tough out there. What can I do for you today?"
 "Well, I was hoping you could help me with some housing options. I've been couch surfing for a few months now and it's really starting to wear on me."
 "Absolutely. We have a few different options for people in your situation. Let's go over them and see what might work best for you."
 'Alright, that sounds great. Thank you so much for your help.'
 "No problem at all. That's what I'm here for."]

head: PersonX suggests seeking counseling
literal: Knight suggests seeking counseling. Now Knight is helped by a counselor.
