["Hey John, I noticed that you've been looking pretty down lately. What's going on?"
 "Yeah, I've just been feeling really overwhelmed and stressed out lately. Everything seems like it's just piling up on me and I can't keep up."
 "That sounds tough. I can definitely relate to feeling like that. I actually started seeing a counselor a while back and it's helped me a lot. Maybe you could try something like that too?"
 "I don't know, I'm not really sure if counseling is for me. Do you think it would help?"
 "Well, it helped me a lot in dealing with my stress and anxiety. It might be worth giving it a shot. Just talking to someone who can help you understand your thoughts and feelings can be really helpful. And if nothing else, it's always good to have someone to talk to who will understand what you're going through."
 "Alright, I'll give it a try. Thank you for suggesting it."
 'No problem, John. I just want to see you happy and stress-free. Let me know how it goes!']

head: PersonX saves his marriage
literal: Emerald saves his marriage. Now Emerald feels pleased.
narrative: Emerald saves his marriage by going to couple's counseling with his wife. He learns how to communicate better and compromise on things. As a result, his relationship with his wife improves significantly.
dialogue:
["I'm sorry for the way I've been behaving. I know I've been taking you for granted and not listening to you."
 "It's okay, I know you're under a lot of stress with work."
 "Yeah, I am. But that's no excuse for the way I've been treating you. I want to make things right."
 'We can go to counseling if you think that would help.'
 'Yeah, I think that would be a good idea.' "Okay, let's do it."
 'Thank you for being understanding. I love you.' 'I love you too.']

head: PersonX goes back to counseling
literal: Kristopher goes back to counseling. Now Kristopher gets better.
narrative: Kristopher realizes that they need to talk to somebody about what's going on, so they make an appointment with a counselor. They start going to counseling sessions once a week and talking about everything that's been going on. Slowly but surely, Kristopher starts to feel better and more like themselves again.
dialogue:
['Hey, how are you doing today?'
 "I'm doing well, thank you. How about you?"
 "I'm feeling a little better today. I've been going to counseling for a few weeks now and it's helping me to talk about everything that's been going on."
 "That's great to hear! It sounds like you're really starting to make some progress."
 "Yeah, I think so too. It's been a long road, but I feel like I'm finally starting to see the light at the end of the tunnel."
 "That's fantastic! What do you think has been helping you the most with your recovery?"
 "Just talking about everything that's happened, and knowing that I'm not alone in this anymore. It's been really hard, but slowly but surely I'm starting to feel better and more like myself again. Thank you for being here for me, it means a lot."]

head: PersonX visits a counselor
literal: Betsy visits a counselor. Now Betsy learns to talk.
narrative: Betsy visits a counselor to learn how to communicate better. The counselor helps Betsy understand the importance of communication and how to express himself. Through the counseling sessions, Betsy learns how to open up and talk about his feelings.
dialogue:
['Hey, thanks for seeing me.' 'Of course. How are you doing today?'
 "I'm feeling a little better, I guess. I'm just having some trouble communicating with people lately."
 "That's understandable. It can be tough to communicate when you're feeling down. Can you tell me more about what's going on?"
 "Yeah. I just feel like no one ever really understands what I'm saying or how I'm feeling. And it's frustrating because I know what I want to say, but it never comes out the way that I want it to."
 "Well, let's start with why you think that is. Do you have any ideas?"
 "Uh, well...I don't know, honestly. It just seems like every time I try to talk to someone, they either don't listen or they get mad at me for no reason. And it makes me not want to talk at all because why bother if no one cares anyway, right? But then that makes things worse because then people think there's something wrong with me and they start avoiding me and it's this big vicious cycle."
 'Yes, communication can be very difficult sometimes especially when we\'re feeling down or frustrated. But it sounds like you have a lot of insight into your situation which is great! So let\'s work on some strategies for how you can communicate more effectively even when you\'re feeling upset or frustrated."']

head: PersonX works as a personal trainer
literal: Argenis works as a personal trainer. Now Argenis makes money.
narrative: Argenis charges $40 per hour for personal training services. She trains her clients in her home gym, and she also provides nutritional counseling. Argenis has been a personal trainer for five years, and she loves helping people reach their fitness goals.
dialogue:
['Hi, thanks for coming by! Have you ever worked with a personal trainer before?'
 'Nope, this would be my first time.'
 "Well, I'll just need to get some basic information from you before we get started. How old are you?"
 "I'm 32." 'And what is your current weight?' '197 pounds.'
 'Okay. And what are your fitness goals? Are you looking to lose weight, gain muscle, or both?'
 'I would like to lose weight and tone up my body overall.'
 "Great! I think I can definitely help you with that. Based on your current weight and fitness goals, I would recommend starting with three personal training sessions per week. Each session will last for one hour, and we'll focus on a different area of your body each day. In addition to the personal training, I also offer nutritional counseling. This is an important part of reaching your goals, as diet plays a big role in weight loss. Would you be interested in that as well?"
 'Yes, that sounds good.'
 "Wonderful! So based on all of this, my recommended package for you would be 12 personal training sessions and 12 nutritional counseling sessions. The total cost for this would be $960. Does that sound like something you're interested in?"
 "Yes, I'll take it!"]

head: PersonX is given counseling
literal: Daniela is given counseling. Now Daniela is more patient.
narrative: Daniela is given counseling. The counselor helps Daniela to see that he needs to be more patient. With the help of the counselor, Daniela is able to be more patient.
dialogue:
["I just don't understand why things have to take so long. I mean, I know that's how life is, but it just seems like everything takes forever."
 "Daniela, patience is a virtue. It's something that we all have to learn in life. Just because something takes time doesn't mean it's not worth doing."
 "I know that, but it's just so hard when you're used to getting things done right away. Everything feels like it's moving in slow motion."
 "That can be frustrating, but remember that good things come to those who wait. If you're patient, eventually things will start moving at the pace you want them to."
 "I guess you're right. It's just hard to be patient when you feel like you're constantly waiting for things to happen."
 'Patience is a muscle that gets stronger with use. The more you practice being patient, the easier it will become. Just keep remind yourself that good things come to those who wait and eventually your patience will pay off.']

head: PersonX becomes a member of the clergy
literal: Polly becomes a member of the clergy. Now Polly wants to be a minister.
narrative: Polly becomes a member of the clergy and is ordained as a minister. He serves in a church and preaches sermons every week. Polly also performs weddings and funerals, and provides counseling to parishioners.
dialogue:
['Hi, Mary. How are you doing today?'
 "Not so good, Polly. My husband just left me and I'm feeling really lost and alone."
 "I'm so sorry to hear that, Mary. What can I do to help you?"
 'Just being here for me is helping a lot. I appreciate your time and your willingness to listen.'
 'Of course, anything I can do to help. Do you want to talk about what happened?'
 "He said he just wasn't happy anymore and needed some space. But I know there must be more to it than that. We've been together for 30 years and I can't imagine my life without him."
 'It\'s natural for you to feel like this right now, Mary. You\'ve been through a major life change and it\'s going to take some time for you to adjust. The most important thing is that you don\'t try to do everything on your own. Let others help you and support you through this tough time."']

head: PersonX gets a reputation for fighting
literal: Lexa gets a reputation for fighting. Now Lexa is a bully.
narrative: Lexa gets a reputation for fighting. Lexa gets into fights with other kids at school, and he even beats up his little sister sometimes. His parents are fed up with his behavior and send him to counseling.
dialogue:
['Hey.' 'Hi, Lexa. How are you doing today?' "I'm alright. I guess."
 "That's good. So, what's been going on that's been bothering you?"
 "It's just, like, everything. School sucks, my parents are always on my case, and I can never do anything right. And now everyone at school is calling me a bully because I got into a few fights. But it wasn't my fault! They were picking on me first!"
 "I see. So you feel like you're not being treated fairly and that people are picking on you?"
 "Yeah! And even my little sister is scared of me now because I beat her up a couple times when she wouldn't stop crying or something. My parents are so mad at me all the time and they keep sending me to counseling and nothing ever helps!"
 "Well, Lexa, let's try to talk about some of this stuff and see if we can figure out a way to help you feel better about things. Do you want to start with why you think your parents are mad at you all the time?"
 "I don't know. They just are. They're always telling me I need to do better in school and stop getting into fights and stuff. But it's like, no matter what I do, they're never happy with me."
 "Well, maybe we can talk about some specific things that you feel like you're being criticised for and see if we can come up with a plan to help you improve in those areas. Would that be okay?"
 'Yeah, I guess so.']

head: PersonX goes back to counseling
literal: Macario goes back to counseling. Now Macario feels motivated.
narrative: Macario attends counseling sessions regularly and feels motivated to work on his issues. He discusses his progress with his counselor and feels proud of the changes he has made.
dialogue:
["I'm really proud of the progress I've made in counseling. I feel like I've really opened up and been honest about my feelings and what's going on in my life. My counselor has been a great help in providing me with guidance and support."
 "That's great to hear, Macario. Can you tell me more about what you feel you've accomplished in counseling?"
 "Well, like I said, I feel like I've been more honest about my feelings and what's going on in my life. I think that's been a big help in itself. Just being able to talk openly and honestly about things has made me feel better. And my counselor has been really helpful in providing me with guidance and support."
 "That sounds like it's been very beneficial for you. Are there any specific areas that you feel you've made progress in?"
 "Yeah, I think just overall my mental health has improved. I'm feeling less anxious and stressed than I used to. And I'm also sleeping better now, which is something that was really affecting me before. So overall, just feeling better mentally and physically."
 "That sounds excellent, Macario! It sounds like counseling is really helping you in a lot of ways. Are there any other benefits that you've noticed?"
 "Yeah, I think counseling has also helped me be more mindful of my thoughts and actions. Like, before I would sometimes do things without thinking about the consequences or how it would affect other people. But now I'm more aware of those things and try to make sure that my actions are positive and not harmful to others. So overall just feeling more mindful and conscientious of my thoughts and actions."]

head: PersonX finds hope and self-esteem in counseling
literal: Ameir finds hope and self-esteem in counseling. Now Ameir is able to express herself.
narrative: Ameir feels hopeless and has low self-esteem, but finds hope in counseling. She is able to express herself better after some sessions and builds up her self-esteem.
dialogue:
["I just feel so hopeless. I don't know what to do with my life."
 'Why do you feel that way, Ameir?'
 "I just don't see any point in anything. Everything feels so pointless and I can't seem to find any meaning in anything."
 "That sounds very difficult. Can you tell me more about how you're feeling?"
 "I just feel like there's nothing good in my life. I'm stuck in this dead-end job, I have no friends or family, and I just can't seem to find any joy in anything. It all feels so pointless."
 "It sounds like you're feeling quite lonely and down on yourself. Have you been getting out and doing things that make you happy?"
 "No, not really. I've been too scared to try new things because I'm afraid of failing or being rejected. So, I've just been staying home a lot lately and not really doing much of anything."
 "That isolation can definitely make things worse when we're already feeling down on ourselves. Maybe we can work on some coping skills for when those negative feelings come up so that you don't get pulled into that dark place again? Would that be something you'd be interested in?"
 "Yeah, I think that would help. I really don't want to feel like this anymore."
 "Okay, let's start with some deep breathing exercises. Close your eyes and take a few deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Slowly count to four as you inhale and then count to eight as you exhale."]

head: PersonX gets treatment
literal: Teddy gets treatment. Now Teddy wants to get better.
narrative: Teddy enters treatment for his addiction. He is committed to getting better and follows the program closely. He attends group meetings and counseling sessions, and after a few months of hard work, Teddy completes treatment.
dialogue:
["It feels really good to have completed treatment and to be on the other side of addiction. I'm grateful for everything that you've done for me and for helping me get my life back on track."
 "Congratulations, Teddy! It's great to see you doing so well. Addiction is a difficult battle, but you've fought hard and come out victorious. I'm proud of you."
 "Thank you, counselor. I couldn't have done it without your help."
 "You're welcome, but I didn't do anything that you didn't already have the power to do. You're the one who's done all the work; I just provided some guidance along the way."
 "That may be true, but without your help and support, I don't know if I would've been able to make it through treatment. So, thank you from the bottom of my heart."
 "You're very welcome, Teddy."]

head: PersonX enters counseling
tail: is able to express her feelings
literal: Joycelyn enters counseling. Now Joycelyn is able to express her feelings.
narrative: Joycelyn enters counseling with a sense of trepidation but also hope. She has been struggling to cope with her feelings and is hoping that counseling will help her to understand and express herself better. Joycelyn is relieved when the counselor proves to be understanding and supportive, and she slowly begins to open up about her feelings and experiences.
dialogue:
["I guess I just don't really know where to start."
 "That's perfectly understandable. Why don't we start with how you're feeling right now?"
 "I'm feeling kind of nervous and scared, but also hopeful. I've been struggling to cope with my feelings and I'm hoping counseling will help me to understand and express myself better."
 "It sounds like you're carrying a lot of weight on your shoulders. Can you tell me more about what's going on for you?"
 "It's just been really tough lately. I feel like I can't talk to anyone about how I'm really feeling, so I end up bottling everything up inside until it feels like it's going to explode. And then when something does happen, like a fight with a friend or a bad grade on a test, it all comes out at once and I end up feeling overwhelmed and hopeless. But then after some time passes, I'll start to feel better again and things will seem manageable again, until the cycle starts all over again."
 "It sounds like you're stuck in a negative feedback loop that's leaving you feeling drained emotionally. Do you think that counseling could help you break out of that cycle?"
 "Yes, I definitely think so. Just talking about what's going on has already helped me to feel better. And knowing that someone is here to listen without judging or trying to fix me makes me feel more hopeful that things can get better."
 "I'm glad to hear that you're feeling more hopeful. What are your thoughts about coming back for another session?"
 'Yes, I would like to come back.']

head: PersonX explains PersonX's purposes
literal: Chrissy explains Chrissy's purposes. Now Chrissy feels enlightened.
narrative: Chrissy is a place for people to go when they need help. It is a place where people can find shelter, food, and clothing. Chrissy also provides services such as job training and counseling.
dialogue:
['Hi, welcome to Chrissy. How can I help you?'
 "Well, I'm not really sure. I guess I just need some help."
 'Okay, what do you need help with?'
 "I don't know. I just feel like I can't do anything right. Everything is a mess and I don't know where to start."
 "It sounds like you are feeling overwhelmed and hopeless. We can help you figure out what is going on and how to get back on track. Let's start with your name and why you came in today."
 "My name is Sarah and I just feel like I can't do anything right. Everything is a mess and I don't know where to start."
 "Okay Sarah, let's take a step back and figure out what's going on. What has been going on that has made you feel this way?"]

head: PersonX needs counseling
literal: Kaizen is sad. Kaizen needs counseling.
narrative: Kaizen is sad because she just broke up with her boyfriend of two years. She is finding it hard to adjust to being single again and is feeling lonely. Kaizen is considering counseling to help her deal with her break-up and learn how to be single again.
dialogue:
["I just feel so lost right now. I don't know how to be single again after being in a relationship for so long."
 "It's understandable that you're feeling this way, Kaizen. Can you tell me more about your relationship? What was it like?"
 'It was great at first. We were always laughing and having fun together. But then things started to change and we started fighting a lot. We would go days without speaking to each other. And then he would cheat on me and I would find out and we would break up and then get back together again. It was like a never-ending cycle.'
 "That sounds really difficult, Kaizen. No wonder you're feeling so lost right now. It sounds like your relationship was pretty toxic."
 "Yeah, I guess it was. I just don't know how to do this whole dating thing again. I'm not even sure I want to date anyone else after what happened with my ex-boyfriend."
 "That's totally understandable, Kaizen. You don't have to jump into dating if you're not ready for it yet. Just take some time for yourself and focus on healing from your past relationship before you think about dating again"]

head: PersonX finds hope and self-esteem in counseling
literal: Aulani finds hope and self-esteem in counseling. Now Aulani is encouraged to move forward.
narrative: Aulani finds hope and self-esteem in counseling. She starts to feel better about herself and her future after talking to her counselor. She is encouraged to keep moving forward with her life.
dialogue:
["I'm really struggling right now. I don't know how to keep going."
 "Aulani, it sounds like you're feeling pretty hopeless right now. I want you to know that it's okay to feel this way, but it's important to remember that things can and will get better. You are strong and capable of overcoming this difficult time. I believe in you and I know that you can do this."
 'Thank you so much for saying that. It means a lot to me. Just hearing you say that I can do this makes me feel a little better already.'
 "That's great! Remember, we are here for you and we will support you every step of the way. You are not alone in this"]

head: PersonX's life turns around
literal: Leighanna's life turns around. Now Leighanna wants to have a better life.
narrative: Now Leighanna is determined to turn her life around. She starts by getting a job and then begins working on getting her GED. She also starts attending counseling sessions to help her deal with her past.
dialogue:
["I've been doing a lot of thinking lately, and I'm just not sure who I am anymore."
 'Who do you want to be?'
 "I don't know. I used to have all these dreams and goals, but they all seem so out of reach now."
 "Leighanna, you've been through a lot in the past few years. It's understandable that you might feel lost right now. But I think it's important for you to remember that you are not defined by your past. You can choose who you want to be going forward."
 "That's easy for you to say. You haven't had your life turned upside down like I have."
 'Leighanna, your past does not have to dictate your future. Yes, it may have shaped who you are, but it does not have to define you. You can choose to change the course of your life at any time. The first step is identifying what it is that you want for yourself and then taking action towards achieving it.'
 "I'm just not sure what I want anymore."
 "Well, let's start with some basics then. What do you enjoy doing?"
 "I used to love painting and drawing, but I haven't done either of those things in years."
 'Why not?' "I don't know. It just doesn't seem important anymore."
 "Leighanna, art is a very important part of who you are. It's a way for you to express yourself and your creativity. There's no reason why you shouldn't continue doing it if it makes you happy."
 "You're right. I should start painting again. Thanks for reminding me of that."]

head: PersonX goes back to counseling
literal: Chioma goes back to counseling. Now Chioma feels encouraged.
narrative: Chioma had been dealing with a lot of personal issues and she felt like she needed to talk to someone. She decided to go back to counseling and she felt encouraged after her first session. Chioma was able to talk about all of her struggles and she felt like the counselor really understood her.
dialogue:
["I'm really struggling right now. I've been going through a lot lately and I just feel like I need to talk to someone."
 "Yes, it sounds like you've been going through a lot. How are you feeling?"
 "I'm feeling really overwhelmed and stressed out. I just feel like everything is piling up on me and I can't handle it all."
 "That sounds very difficult. Can you tell me more about what's going on?"
 "Well, my mom has been sick and she's in the hospital right now. I've been taking care of her and my little sister while my dad is at work. It's just been really hard because I'm trying to balance school and taking care of my family. On top of that, my grandparents have been having some health problems too, so I've been helping them out as well. It's just a lot to deal with all at once and I don't know how much longer I can keep this up."
 "Wow, it sounds like you're carrying a lot on your shoulders right now. You're doing an amazing job, but it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling?"
 "No, not really. My friends try to be supportive, but they don't really understand what I'm dealing with because they haven't had any experience with this sort of thing before. And my family is dealing with their own stuff too, so they're not really able to support me the way that I need them to right now."
 "That makes sense. It can be difficult when we don't have anyone who understands what we're going through or who can relate to our situation. But it sounds like you're reaching out for help which is a very positive step forward"
 "Yeah, I guess I just needed to talk to someone who would understand. It's been really hard lately and I feel like I'm at my breaking point."
 "Yes, it sounds like it has been very difficult for you. But you're doing an incredible job considering all that you're dealing with. You are very strong and you can get through this. We will work together to figure out a plan to help you manage everything that you're dealing with."]

head: PersonX is haunted by his past
literal: Lamiyah is haunted by his past. Now Lamiyah decides to seek counseling.
narrative: Lamiyah had been dealing with a lot of trauma from his past and felt like he needed to seek counseling. He met with a counselor weekly and started to feel better about himself. However, he still struggled with nightmares and flashbacks of his past.
dialogue:
["I still have a lot of nightmares about my childhood. I'll be doing something totally innocuous and then all of a sudden I'm reliving some really terrible moment. It's like my brain can't stop thinking about it."
 "That sounds very difficult to deal with. Do you feel like you're able to talk about those experiences with anyone?"
 "Not really. I mean, I've tried talking to my friends about it, but they just don't get it. And my family definitely doesn't want to hear anything about it. They just want me to move on and forget about it. But I can't forget about it, you know? It's like those memories are burned into my brain."
 "Yes, Lamiyah, I understand what you're saying. It sounds like you've been through a lot in your life and that can certainly take a toll on someone's mental health. What I want you to know is that you are not alone in this experience and there are people who care about you and want to help you heal from your trauma."
 "Thank you for saying that. Just knowing that there are people out there who understand what I'm going through makes me feel a little bit better already."
 'You\'re welcome, Lamiyah. We are here for you whenever you need us."']

head: PersonX refuses to go for counseling
literal: Braydon refuses to go for counseling because Braydon wants to avoid counseling.
narrative: Braydon refused to go for counseling because she felt it would be pointless. She thought that her problems were too personal and complicated to discuss with a stranger, and she didn't want to rehash old pain.
dialogue:
["John, I really don't think counseling is going to help us. Our problems are too personal and complicated to discuss with a stranger."
 "But Braydon, we've been through so much pain. Maybe it would be helpful to talk to someone who could help us understand our feelings and work through our issues."
 "I don't want to rehash old pain. It's too painful to relive those memories."
 'But maybe it would be cathartic for you to talk about what happened. We could benefit from some guidance on how to deal with our pain.'
 "I don't know...I'm just not sure if it would be worth it."]

head: PersonX enters counseling
literal: Jarad enters counseling. Now Jarad is diagnosed with depression.
narrative: Jarad enters counseling. After a few sessions, her counselor diagnoses her with depression and prescribes medication. Jarad takes the medication as prescribed and begins to feel better.
dialogue:
["I'm feeling much better, thank you. The medication is really helping."
 "I'm glad to hear that. How are things going at home and at work?"
 "Work is good. I got a raise and a promotion recently, so that's been great. At home, things are okay. My husband and I are getting along better since I've been taking the medication. We're communicating more and he's been supportive."
 "That's sounds like progress. Are there any other areas in your life that you're struggling with?"
 "I guess I'm just struggling with self-esteem issues. I still don't feel confident even though my husband tells me how beautiful I am and my friends say nice things about me too. It's hard for me to believe them sometimes."
 'It sounds like you have some negative beliefs about yourself that you need to work on challenged. Can we talk about some of those beliefs? Do you think that you deserve to be happy?'
 "No, I don't think so. I mean, I know I should be grateful for what I have, but I just can't seem to shake this feeling that I don't deserve good things."
 'Why do you feel that way?'
 "I guess it's just because of the way I grew up. My parents were always critical of me and nothing I ever did was good enough for them. They would compare me to my sister and tell me how much better she was than me. As a result, I've always felt like I'm not good enough and that no matter what I do, it's never going to be enough."
 "That's a really tough way to grow up. It sounds like you've internalized your parent's beliefs about you and now you believe them yourself. We need to work on challenging those beliefs and replacing them with more positive ones. Can you think of any times when you have been successful or proud of yourself?"
 "Yes, there have been times when I've been proud of myself. For example, when I got the promotion at work or when my friends tell me how well I'm doing despite everything that's happened in my life."
 'Those are great examples! What do you think those accomplishments say about you?'
 'They say that maybe I am capable of good things after all. Maybe my parents were wrong about me and maybe I am worthy of happiness after all.'
 "Exactly! Those are great realizations to come to Jarad! Let's continue to work on challenged your negative beliefs about yourself and replacing them with more positive ones"]

head: PersonX grieves because of PersonY
literal: Teaghan grieves because of Renzo. Now Teaghan wants to feel better.
narrative: Teaghan is grieving because her boyfriend, Renzo, died. She wants to feel better, so she goes to counseling and starts talking about her feelings.
dialogue:
["I miss you so much, Renzo. I can't believe you're gone."
 "I'm sorry, Teaghan. I wish I could be there for you."
 "It's just so hard to accept that you're gone. I keep thinking that you'll come back to me."
 "I wish I could, but sadly, that's not possible. death is final."
 "Why did this have to happen? We were supposed to be together forever. Now, I'm all alone."
 'Teaghan, try to remember all the happy times we had together. focus on those memories and cherish them. That\'s what will help get you through this tough time."']

head: PersonX finds hope and self-esteem in counseling
literal: Mckensie finds hope and self-esteem in counseling. Now Mckensie wants to be a counselor.
narrative: Mckensie has been attending counseling sessions for the past few months and has found them to be incredibly helpful. She feels more confident and hopeful about her future than she ever has before, and she is now considering becoming a counselor herself so that she can help others who are going through similar struggles.
dialogue:
['Hi, thanks for seeing me again.' 'Of course, how are you doing?'
 "I'm doing good, I think. I'm feeling more confident and hopeful than I ever have before. Counseling has really helped me a lot."
 "That's great to hear! What do you think has been the most helpful part of counseling for you?"
 "Just being able to talk about everything that's going on in my life and getting some unbiased feedback. It's helped me to see things from a different perspective and realize that there is hope for my future."
 "That makes sense. It can be really eye-opening to talk to someone who isn't directly involved in your situation and can offer impartial advice. Did anything else stand out to you as being helpful?"
 "Yeah, just the overall atmosphere of the sessions. Knowing that I can come here and talk about anything without judgement has been really freeing for me. And it's nice to know that there's someone who cares about what happens to me and wants to help me through tough times."
 'Absolutely. We want to be here for you and help you in any way we can. So it sounds like counseling has been a really positive experience for you overall?'
 "Yeah, definitely. I would recommend it to anyone who is struggling with anything in their life. It's helped me more than I ever could have imagined."
 "That's great to hear! We're so glad we could help you through this difficult time in your life."]

head: PersonX is given counseling
literal: Zeth is given counseling. Now Zeth feels upset.
narrative: Zeth is given counseling. He feels uncomfortable and exposed discussing his personal life with a stranger. He leaves the session feeling worse than when he arrived.
dialogue:
['Hi.' 'Hi, Zeth. How are you doing today?' "I'm okay, I guess."
 "What's been going on that's had you coming to see me?"
 "It's just, ever since my wife died, I've been feeling really lost and alone. I don't know how to cope with it."
 'That sounds very difficult. How long ago did she die?'
 "It's been about six months now."
 "And in that time, how have you been coping? Have you been talking to anyone about how you're feeling?"
 "No, not really. I mean, I've talked to my friends and family a little bit, but it's just not the same as talking to someone who understands what I'm going through."
 "So you feel like nobody really understands what you're going through?"
 "Yeah, that's exactly it. I feel like nobody gets it."
 'That must be very isolating for you. Have you tried joining any support groups or anything like that?'
 "No, I haven't really looked into that kind of thing."
 'Well, maybe that could be something worth considering. It can be helpful to talk to people who are going through similar things as you are.'
 "Yeah, maybe that would help...I don't know...I just feel so lost right now and I don't know how to find my way back..."]

head: PersonX enters counseling
literal: Elia enters counseling because Elia wants to get help.
narrative: Elia enters counseling because Elia wants to talk to someone about the anxiety and depression he has been struggling with for the past few months. He has been feeling increasingly overwhelmed and hopeless, and has been having trouble functioning at work and in his personal life. He is hoping that counseling will help him learn how to cope with his mental health issues and make some positive changes in his life.
dialogue:
['Hi, thanks for seeing me.'
 'Of course, thank you for coming in. How are you doing today?'
 "I'm feeling pretty overwhelmed and hopeless today. I've been struggling with anxiety and depression for the past few months, and it's been really tough to function at work and in my personal life. I'm hoping that counseling will help me learn how to cope with my mental health issues and make some positive changes in my life."
 "It sounds like you're going through a lot right now. I'm glad you came in to talk to someone about what's going on. Can you tell me more about your anxiety and depression? What are some of the things that trigger your symptoms?"
 "Well, lately it seems like everything has been triggering my symptoms. I'm just constantly feeling anxious and stressed out, and it's really hard to concentrate or enjoy anything anymore. My sleep has been really messed up too - I either can't fall asleep or I wake up a million times during the night. And then during the day I just feel completely exhausted all the time. As for my depression, it's just this constant feeling of sadness and emptiness that comes over me. Everything feels pointless and like there's no hope for anything better in life. Just getting out of bed in the morning is a huge struggle most days."
 'It sounds like your anxiety and depression are really taking a toll on your daily life. That must be very difficult to deal with on a daily basis. Have you ever talked to anyone else about your mental health before?'
 "No, I've never really talked to anyone about it. I guess I've just been afraid of being judged or seen as weak. But it's gotten to the point where I can't keep pretending like everything is okay, so I decided to come in for counseling."
 "Well, I'm glad you made that decision. It takes a lot of courage to seek help, and I admire you for doing that. I think counseling can definitely be beneficial for you. We can work on identifying your triggers and learning some coping skills to help you deal with your anxiety and depression in a more healthy way. We can also talk about ways to make positive changes in your life that will help you feel better overall. Does that sound like something you would be interested in doing?"
 'Yes, definitely. I really want to learn how to cope with my mental health issues in a healthier way and make some positive changes in my life.']

head: PersonX suggests seeking counseling
literal: Aila is wise. Aila suggests seeking counseling.
narrative: Aila is a very wise person. He suggested that I seek counseling in order to help me with my problem. I took his advice and found a counselor who has helped me immensely.
dialogue:
['You know, I think it might be a good idea for you to seek out counseling.'
 'Why do you say that?'
 "Well, from what you've told me, it sounds like you're going through a lot and could use some professional help."
 "Yeah, I guess you're right. I never thought about counseling before."
 "It's definitely worth considering. The therapist can help you sort out your thoughts and figure out a plan to move forward."
 "That does sound helpful. I'll look into it. Thank you for suggesting it, Aila."]

head: PersonX goes back to counseling
literal: Andree goes back to counseling. Now Andree feels hopeful.
narrative: Andree goes back to counseling. The therapist helps Andree understand his feelings and gives him tools to deal with anxiety. Andree feels hopeful and is able to talk about his problems without feeling so overwhelmed.
dialogue:
["I've been feeling really anxious lately. I don't know what to do."
 'What specifically are you feeling anxious about?'
 "I'm just worried about everything. My job, my relationships, the future. I feel like I can't handle it all."
 "It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and like you're not sure how to cope with all that's going on in your life."
 "Yeah, that's it exactly. I don't know what to do or where to turn."
 "Well, let's talk about some of the things that are going on in your life that are causing you stress. Maybe we can brainstorm some coping strategies together."
 'Okay, that sounds good.' "So, what's going on with your job?"
 "I'm just really worried about losing my job. My company is going through some tough times and there have been layoffs. I just feel like I'm constantly worrying about being next."
 "It's understandable that you would feel anxious in that situation. Have you been able to talk to your boss or anyone at work about how you're feeling?"
 "No, I haven't really said anything to them. I don't want to seem like I'm not coping well or that I can't handle the stress."
 "Well, it might be worth talking to your boss or someone at work that you trust about how you're feeling and see if they have any advice or reassurance for you. As far as coping strategies go, have you tried things like relaxation techniques or exercise?"
 "Yeah, I've tried those things but they don't really seem to help much."
 'Well, sometimes it takes a little bit of trial and error to find something that works for you. Maybe we can brainstorm some other ideas together and see if anything else sounds helpful.']

head: PersonX is given counseling
literal: Gerardo is given counseling. Now Gerardo is treated for depression.
narrative: Gerardo was given counseling to help with their depression. The counselor helped Gerardo to understand their thoughts and feelings, and develop coping mechanisms to deal with them. Gerardo is now doing better and is able to manage their depression.
dialogue:
['Thank you so much for seeing me on such short notice.'
 "It's no problem at all. How are you doing today?"
 "I've been better. I'm just feeling really down lately and I don't know why."
 "Well, let's talk about what's been going on in your life recently. Maybe that will help us figure out what might be causing your depression."
 "Okay. Well, I've just been feeling really isolated lately. I moved to a new city for work and I don't really know anyone here. And on top of that, my job is really stressful and I'm not sure if it's the right fit for me. So I guess I'm just feeling kind of lost right now."
 "That makes sense. It sounds like you're going through a lot of changes in your life right now, which can be tough to deal with. Have you been trying to reach out and connect with people in your new city?"
 "Yeah, I've gone to a few meetups and things like that but it's hard when you don't have anyone to really connect with on a deeper level. And even when I am around people, I feel like they can tell that something is off with me and it makes me feel even more isolated."
 'That sounds very difficult to deal with. Isolation can be a big trigger for depression, so we need to try to find some ways to combat that for you. Have you considered joining any social clubs or groups? Or maybe volunteering somewhere? Getting involved in activities where you can meet new people and make friends can be a great way to help reduce feelings of loneliness and isolation."'
 "Yeah, I've been thinking about joining a book club or something like that. I just haven't had the motivation to do it lately."
 'That\'s understandable. When you\'re feeling down, it can be hard to find the motivation to do anything. But it\'s important to try to push through those feelings and do something that will make you feel better. Why don\'t we brainstorm a few ideas of things you can do when you\'re feeling lonely or isolated? That way, when those feelings come up, you\'ll have a plan of action to help combat them."']

head: PersonX begins a counseling session
tail: to be assigned to a counselor

narrative: Emili was assigned to a counselor. During the counseling session, Emili discussed his struggles with anxiety and depression. The counselor offered Emili some coping strategies and resources to help him manage his symptoms.
dialogue:
["Hey, thanks for meeting with me today. I've been struggling a lot lately with anxiety and depression and I'm really not sure what to do."
 "Absolutely, Emili. It sounds like you're feeling really overwhelmed right now. Can you tell me more about what's going on?"
 "Yeah, it's just been tough lately. I feel like I can't focus on anything or enjoy anything anymore. Everything feels so gray and bleak. And my anxiety is through the roof. I'm constantly worrying about things that might happen or things that could go wrong and it's just exhausting."
 'That does sound very tough to deal with on a daily basis. Have you tried any coping mechanisms or strategies in the past?'
 "Yeah, I've tried some deep breathing exercises and things like that but they don't really seem to help much. And I've talked to my friends and family about it but it's just hard for them to understand what I'm going through."
 "Well, one thing we can do is work on some specific strategies that may help you manage your anxiety and depression symptoms day-to-day. But it sounds like it would also be helpful for you to talk about how you're feeling with people who are supportive and understanding too. Would that be something you'd be interested in doing?"
 'Yeah, I think that would be really helpful. Thanks for suggesting it.'
 "Of course. Let's go ahead and brainstorm some ideas of people you could talk to and some specific things you might want to say."]

head: PersonX suggests seeking counseling

narrative: Briyana decides that she wants to get better and seek counseling. She makes an appointment with a therapist and starts attending weekly sessions. Through counseling, Briyana begins to understand her mental illness and how to manage it.
dialogue:
["I really appreciate you seeing me, therapist. I've been struggling a lot lately and I'm not sure what to do."
 "Thank you for coming in, Briyana. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?"
 "Well, I've been feeling really down and helpless lately. I can't concentrate at work and my relationships have suffered because of it. I just feel like everything is falling apart and I don't know how to fix it."
 "It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of anxiety and depression. Do you think that might be what's going on?"
 "Yes, I guess that could be it. But it feels like there's something more to it than just that."
 "That's understandable. It can be hard to pinpoint exactly what we're feeling when we're going through a tough time. But from what you're saying, it sounds like your mental illness is starting to interfere with your life in a significant way. Have you considered seeking counseling or therapy to help you deal with this?"
 "Yes, actually, that's why I'm here today. I want to get better and I know I need help to do that."
 "That's great! Seeking help is always the first step in managing any mental illness. Together, we'll work on identifying your symptoms and developing coping strategies to help you deal with them effectively."]

 'That would be great. I really appreciate your help.' "You're welcome."]

head: PersonX enters counseling

dialogue:
['Hi.' 'Hi, Aryssa. How are you today?'
 "I'm okay, I guess. Just feeling a little down about myself."
 "What's been going on that's got you feeling this way?"
 "It's just that I feel like I'm too short and that people are always staring at me because of it. It makes me feel really self-conscious and uncomfortable."
 "That sounds tough. Can you tell me more about how you're feeling when people stare at you?"
 'It just makes me feel really exposed and vulnerable. Like everyone can see how inadequate I feel and it just makes me want to hide away from the world.'
 'That sounds very isolating and scary. Have you been avoiding situations where you might have to deal with people staring at you?'
 "Yeah, I've been trying to stay at home a lot more and just not go out in public as much. But it's hard because I have to go out for work and stuff."
 'That must be really tough. Can you tell me more about how you feel when you have to go out for work?'
 "I just feel like I have to put on this brave face and pretend like everything is okay. But inside I'm just feeling really scared and alone."
 "It sounds like you're carrying a lot of weight on your shoulders. Do you think talking about your feelings more might help relieve some of that pressure?"
 "Yeah, I think so. It's just really hard for me to open up about this stuff."
 "That's understandable. Can we take some time in each session to talk about how you're feeling? Would that be okay with you?"
 'Yeah, that would be great. Thanks.']

head: PersonX saves his marriage
literal: Filip saves his marriage. Now Filip feels confident.
narrative: Filip was having some trouble in his marriage, but he decided to seek counseling and work on things. He is now happy to report that things are much better between him and his wife, and he feels more confident in himself.
dialogue:
["I'm really happy to be here today, counselor. Things have been rough for me lately, and I really appreciate you seeing me."
 "Of course, Filip. What's been going on that's been causing you distress?"
 "Well, my marriage has been having some difficulties. We've been arguing a lot lately, and I just don't feel like things are going well between us. I love my wife, but I feel like we're growing apart instead of together."
 "That sounds very difficult. Can you tell me more about the arguments you've been having?"
 "It's just that we don't seem to see eye to eye on anything anymore. We used to be so close, but now it feels like we're constantly fighting. And it's not just little things either - it feels like everything is a big deal now. Even something as simple as what to have for dinner can turn into a huge argument."
 "That does sound very difficult. Have you tried talking to your wife about how you're feeling?"
 "Yeah, I have. But it seems like she doesn't really want to listen or understand how I'm feeling. She just gets defensive and says that I'm the one who's causing all the problems in our marriage. But I don't know what else to do - I feel like I'm trying everything and nothing is working."
 "Well, it sounds like you're feeling very frustrated. Have you considered going to couples counseling with your wife?"
 "I have, but she doesn't really want to do that. She says she doesn't see the point since we're just going to end up arguing in front of someone else. But I don't know what else to do - I feel like I'm at a loss."
 "Well, it sounds like you're really struggling right now. But I think it's important to remember that marriages can go through rough patches - it doesn't mean that things can't improve. With time and effort, things can get better."
 "Yeah, I know you're right. It's just been really tough lately and I feel like I'm running out of options."
 "Well, why don't we take some time today and brainstorm some possible solutions? Maybe there's something you haven't tried yet that could make a difference."]

head: PersonX is a counselor

dialogue:
['So, Sarah, how are things going? Has anything been bothering you lately?'
 "Yeah, there have been a few things. I don't know if I can talk about them, though."
 "That's okay, Sarah. Whatever you feel comfortable sharing with me is fine. I'm here to help you in any way I can."
 "It's just that, lately, I've been feeling really down and helpless. Like nothing I do makes any difference."
 'That sounds really tough, Sarah. Can you tell me more about that? What specific things have been going on that have made you feel this way?'
 "Well, school has been really hard for me lately. My grades are slipping and I'm getting into arguments with my friends a lot more often. And at home, my parents are always fighting and they're never happy with anything I do. It feels like no matter what I do, it's never good enough for anyone."
 "That sounds very difficult to deal with, Sarah. It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure from all sides and like you're not sure how to make things better. Have you been trying to talk to anyone about how you're feeling?"
 "Yeah, I've talked to my friends about it and they've been really supportive, but it doesn't seem like anything they say or do makes things better either. And my parents just get mad at me when I try to talk to them about it so I don't even bother anymore. But it feels like everything is just piling up on me and I don't know what to do anymore..."
 "It sounds like you feel completely overwhelmed right now and that nobody understands what you're going through or how you're feeling"]

head: PersonX helps PersonY through the trauma

She is also involved in a community outreach program that provides counseling services to people who have been affected by violence.
dialogue:
['Hey, Kejuan. How are you doing today?'
 "I'm doing all right, thanks for asking. How about you?"
 "I'm doing well, thanks. So, I understand that you were in a car accident recently. Can you tell me what happened?"
 "Yeah, it was pretty bad. I was driving home from work and someone ran a red light and hit me head-on. It was a really scary experience. My car was totaled and I had to be hospitalized for a few days. Thankfully, I'm okay now but it was definitely a close call."
 "I'm so sorry to hear that, Kejuan. That must have been really scary for you. Can you tell me how you're feeling now?"
 "I'm feeling a lot better now, thankfully. But it was definitely a tough experience and I'm still kind of shaken up by it all."
 "That's completely understandable. It sounds like you're doing a great job of managing though, considering everything that happened. Do you have any questions or anything that you want to talk about? We can discuss anything that's on your mind."]

head: PersonX needs counseling
literal: Cobi needs counseling. Now Cobi learns to deal with stress.
narrative: Cobi is dealing with a lot of stress. She needs to learn how to cope with it in a healthy way. Counseling can help her do that.
dialogue:
["I'm just feeling really overwhelmed lately. Everything seems like it's piling up and I don't know how to deal with it."
 "It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure and stress. Are there any specific things that are causing you stress?"
 "Well, my job is really demanding and I feel like I'm never able to get ahead. And then there's just all the normal day-to-day stuff, like taking care of my house and family. It all feels like too much sometimes."
 "It sounds like you have a lot on your plate. It's understandable that you would feel stressed out with all of that going on. Do you have any healthy coping mechanisms or ways of dealing with stress?"
 "I try to take some time for myself every day, even if it's just a few minutes. I'll read or take a bath or go for a walk. And I've been trying to meditate, but it's hard to clear my mind."
 'Those are all great ideas. Taking some time for yourself is definitely important in managing stress. Meditation can be difficult at first, but it can be very helpful in clearing your mind and finding some peace. Are there any other things that you find helpful in dealing with stress?'
 "Talking to my friends always makes me feel better. Just knowing that I'm not alone in feeling stressed out helps a lot. And of course, exercise always helps relieve some tension."
 "Yes, those are all great coping mechanisms. It's important to have supportive people in your life that you can talk to when you're feeling stressed out. Exercise is also a great way to release some of that built up tension and stress. Are there any other things that you do to try and reduce your stress levels?"
 'Not really...I guess I just try to take everything one day at a time and hope that things will eventually get better.'
 'That\'s definitely a good attitude to have. Sometimes all we can do is take things one day at a time and hope for the best. But it sounds like you\'re doing everything you can to manage your stress levels and cope in a healthy way, so that\'s good."']

head: PersonX pursues a master’s degree

narrative: Candy is applying to graduate school. She is hoping to pursue a master's degree in counseling. Candy has always been interested in helping people, and she thinks that this degree will allow her to do just that.
dialogue:
["I'm thinking about applying to graduate school for a master's degree in counseling."
 'That sounds like a great idea! What made you decide that you want to pursue counseling?'
 "Well, I've always been interested in helping people. I think this degree will allow me to do just that. Plus, I really enjoy working with people and hearing their stories."
 "That's terrific! I think you would make an excellent counselor. Do you have any experience working with clients?"
 "Yes, I've interned at a mental health clinic for the past year. It's been a great experience. I've learned a lot about different counseling techniques and how to work with clients."
 "That's great! Having experience working with clients is definitely an asset when applying to graduate programs in counseling. Are there any specific areas of counseling that you're interested in?"
 "Yes, I'm particularly interested in working with children and families. I think it would be really rewarding to help families overcome challenges and improve their relationships."
 "That's terrific! There are many different ways that you could specialize within the field of counseling, so it sounds like you have a good idea of what you want to do. Have you started looking at any specific graduate programs?"
 "Yes, I've been looking at a few different programs. I'm not sure which one I want to apply to yet, but I'm definitely considering it."
 "That's great! There are many different things to consider when choosing a graduate program, so you'll want to make sure you do your research. But I think you would be an excellent counselor, and I'm sure you'll find the right program for you."]

head: PersonX deals with grief
literal: Rayyan deals with grief because Rayyan wants to deal with his emotions.
narrative: Rayyan is grieving the loss of her husband. She wants to deal with her emotions in a healthy way, so she seeks out counseling and therapy. She also spends time with her friends and family, who support her during this difficult time.
dialogue:
["I just feel so lost without him. We were married for nearly 40 years and I just can't imagine my life without him."
 "It's perfectly normal to feel this way after losing a spouse. Can you tell me more about your relationship with him? What did you enjoy most about being married to him?"
 'He was just such a good man. He always put me and our family first, no matter what. I always felt so safe and loved with him. He was just my best friend and I miss him so much.'
 "It sounds like you had a really strong and supportive relationship with him. It's understandable that you're feeling so lost without him now. Have you been able to talk to anyone else about how you're feeling?"
 "Yes, I've been spending a lot of time with my friends and family. They've been really supportive and understanding. I also started seeing a counselor to help me deal with my emotions."
 "That's great that you have such a supportive network of people around you. Counseling can be really helpful in situations like this. Are there any specific things you're struggling with that you'd like to talk about?"
 "I just feel so alone sometimes. Like, he was my everything and now he's gone. I don't know how to move on without him."
 "It's totally normal to feel that way after losing a spouse. You were used to sharing your life with him and now he's gone, so it makes sense that you would feel lost without him. What are some things that you enjoyed doing together? Maybe there are things that you can do to remember him and keep his memory alive."
 'We loved going on walks together and just spending time outdoors. We used to garden together and go for hikes on the weekends. Just being in nature always made us both feel so peaceful and happy.'
 'Those sound like great memories that you can hold onto. Maybe next time you go on a walk or spend time in your garden, you can think of him and all the happy times you shared together. It might help ease some of the pain you\'re feeling."']

head: PersonX’s marriage was breaking up
literal: Jayvon’s marriage was breaking up. Now Jayvon wants to save his marriage.
narrative: Jayvon and her husband have been having difficulty communicating recently, and their arguments have become more frequent. Jayvon is determined to save her marriage, so she has been attending counseling sessions with her husband in hopes of repairing their relationship.
dialogue:
["Our therapist said it would be a good idea for us to talk about what's been going on lately."
 "I'm not sure what there is to talk about. You're the one who's been acting distant and moody."
 "That's not fair. You've been working long hours and you're never home. When you are home, you're always on your phone or watching TV. I feel like I can't even talk to you anymore."
 "Well, you're not exactly easy to talk to either. You always have your nose in a book or you're off with your friends. I feel like I'm the one who's always trying to initiate conversations and you're just not interested."
 "That's not true! I do want to talk to you, but it feels like every time I try, you shut me down or brush me off. It hurts my feelings when you do that."
 "Well, maybe if you would actually listen when I tried to talk to you instead of always interrupting or changing the subject, I wouldn't have to resort to those things!"
 "That's not fair! You make me feel like whatever I have to say isn't important enough for you to listen to. It makes me not want to bother trying anymore."
 'Well, maybe if you would actually say something worth listening to instead of always complaining or nagging, I would be more inclined to listen!'
 "That's not fair! You make me feel like I can't do anything right. It feels like everything is always my fault."
 "Well, maybe if you would actually take some responsibility for once and admit that you're wrong occasionally, I wouldn't feel that way!"
 "That's not fair! You're always making me out to be the bad guy. It makes me feel like I can't win with you no matter what I do."
 "Well, maybe if you would actually try to see things from my perspective and meet me halfway on things, I wouldn't have to be so hard on you all the time!"
 "That's not fair! You're always putting the blame on me and expecting me to change. It makes me feel like I'm not good enough for you."
 "Well, maybe if you would actually try to change some of the things that I've asked you to, I wouldn't have to keep bringing them up all the time!"]

head: PersonX needs counseling
literal: Nyla needs counseling because Nyla wants to get over his fears.
narrative: Nyla was diagnosed with anxiety and has been struggling with fear for many years. She has decided that she wants to get counseling to help her deal with her anxiety and overcome her fears.
dialogue:
["Hi, counselor. I'm here because I want to talk about my anxiety and fears. I've been struggling with both for many years, and I'm finally ready to get some help."
 "Welcome, Nyla. It sounds like you've been through a lot. Let's start by talking about your anxiety. What are some of the things that make you anxious?"
 "Well, pretty much anything can trigger my anxiety. Sometimes it's something as small as a busy street or a loud noise. Other times it might be something bigger, like an upcoming test or presentation at work. And lately, I've been feeling really anxious about the future in general. Just thinking about all the things that could go wrong makes me feel panicked and out of control."
 "I see. It sounds like your anxiety is really affecting your life in a negative way. But it's good that you're here, because we can work on managing your anxiety and helping you to overcome your fears. First of all, let's talk about some of the things you're doing to try to cope with your anxiety on your own. What have you been doing when you start to feel anxious?"
 "Well, lately I've been trying to distract myself by watching TV or scrolling through social media. But that usually doesn't work for long, and then I just end up feeling more anxious. Sometimes I'll try to take deep breaths and relax, but that usually doesn't help either. And sometimes I just have to force myself to keep going even though I'm feeling really scared and panicked inside."
 "It sounds like you're doing the best you can, but it's not really helping in the long run. That's why it's good that you're here, because we can help you to find better ways of coping with your anxiety. For example, we can work on some relaxation techniques that may be more effective for you. We can also talk about your fears and how to address them in a more productive way. Would you like to try some of these things?"
 'Yes, I would love to try anything that might help me feel less anxious and scared.']
