head: PersonX is given counseling
literal: Jarell is given counseling because Jarell wants to be better.
narrative: Jarell was feeling low lately and really wanted to improve his mood and overall wellbeing. He decided to seek out counseling in order to help himself feel better. After talking with a counselor, he felt relief and hope that things would get better for him.
dialogue:
["I'm just feeling really down lately. I don't know what to do or where to turn."
 "It sounds like you're feeling lost and helpless right now. But I want you to know that there is hope and things can get better. We'll work together to figure out what's going on and how to improve your situation."
 "Yeah, I'd like that. I just feel so stuck right now."
 "It sounds like you feel like you're in a rut and you don't see a way out. But we'll work together to find a way out for you. There are always options and solutions, we just have to find the right ones for you."
 "Yeah, I guess you're right. I just feel so down and defeated right now."
 "It sounds like you're feeling really down about yourself right now. But I want you to know that you are not alone and we will figure this out together."]

head: PersonX investigates his own emotions
literal: Patience investigates his own emotions. Now Patience is encouraged to seek counseling.
narrative: Patience begins to feel overwhelmed with his emotions. He feels like he can't control them and they are dictating his life. Patience decides to seek counseling in order to gain a better understanding of his emotions and how to manage them.
dialogue:
['I just feel so overwhelmed all the time. It feels like my emotions are in control of me and not the other way around.'
 "It sounds like you're feeling like you're not in control of your life. Is that accurate?"
 "Yeah, that's definitely it. I'll be fine one minute and then the next I'm angry or upset about something and I don't know why."
 'Have you always felt this way? Or is this a recent development?'
 "It's been getting worse lately. I used to be able to at least fake being happy but now even that's a struggle."
 'What do you think might be causing this sudden change?'
 "I'm not really sure. Everything just seems so overwhelming and difficult lately. I can't focus on anything and everything feels pointless."
 "That sounds very tough to deal with. It sounds like you're feeling hopeless right now. Is there anything in your life that's bringing you joy? Anything that you're looking forward to?"
 "Not really. Everything just seems so pointless. I don't know what I'm doing with my life."
 "That sounds very lost and uncertain. It's normal to feel like that at some points in life, but it sounds like you're feeling that way all the time. Have you considered seeking professional help?"
 "I don't know. I'm not sure if it would even help."
 "Well, it might be worth a try. If you're feeling this hopeless all the time, it's not going to get better on its own. Would you be willing to give counseling a try?"
 'Yeah, I guess so.']

head: PersonX begins a counseling session
literal: Lilyann is wise. Lilyann begins a counseling session.
narrative: Lilyann begins the counseling session by asking the client how their day was. The client responds that their day was good, but they are struggling to cope with a recent loss. Lilyann listens attentively and provides sage advice on how to deal with grief.
dialogue:
["Thank you for sharing that with me. I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. It sounds like you're feeling really lost right now."
 "Yeah, I feel like I'm just treading water. I don't know how to move on from this."
 "Well, it sounds like you're doing the best you can under the circumstances. Grief is a process, and it can be a very difficult one. There are no easy answers, but there are things that can help. I encourage you to talk about your feelings with someone who will understand and can offer support. Don't bottle everything up inside. It's also important to take care of yourself physically. Make sure you're eating right and getting enough rest. Exercise can also be helpful in managing grief and stress. And finally, give yourself time to heal. Grief is not something that you can simply get over overnight. It takes time, patience, and understanding to work through it successfully."
 'Thank you, Lilyann. That was really helpful. Just knowing that there are things I can do to help myself makes me feel a little better already.'
 'I\'m glad to hear that, ____ . We\'ll talk more about this next time we meet, but in the meantime, please don\'t hesitate to reach out if you need anything at all."']

head: PersonX learns to cope
literal: Merci learns to cope. Now Merci is better able to cope.
narrative: Merci had some tough times in her life, but she eventually learned how to deal with them. She went through a lot of counseling and therapy, and eventually she developed some healthy coping mechanisms. Now Merci is much better equipped to handle whatever life throws her way.
dialogue:
["Wow, it feels like it's been forever since I've been here. How are you doing?"
 "I'm doing well, thank you for asking. How about you? It sounds like you've had some tough times lately."
 "Yeah, I have. It's been really hard to deal with everything that's happened. But I'm starting to feel better now. I've been going to counseling and therapy, and I'm learning how to cope in a healthy way. So things are getting better."
 "That's great to hear! I'm glad you're finding some help that's working for you. It sounds like you've been through a lot lately. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?"
 "Well, my mom died a few months ago, and it was really hard to deal with. I felt like I was all alone in the world. But then I started going to counseling and talking to my therapist, and I realized that I wasn't alone. There are people who care about me and want to help me. So that's been helping a lot."
 "I'm so sorry to hear about your mom. That must have been incredibly difficult for you. But it sounds like you're starting to heal and move forward, which is amazing. Keep up the good work!"]

head: PersonX needs counseling
literal: Kaine needs counseling because Kaine wants to be a better person.
narrative: Kaine has been having a lot of negative thoughts lately and he wants to talk to someone about it. He's been feeling like he's not good enough and like everyone is better than him. Kaine hopes that counseling will help him feel better about himself and his life.
dialogue:
["Hi. Thank you for seeing me today. I've been feeling really down lately and I'm hoping counseling will help."
 "Of course, Kaine. Let's start by talking about what's been going on that has you feeling this way."
 "It's just been a lot of things lately. I feel like I'm not good enough and that everyone is better than me. It's been really hard to motivate myself to do anything. I just feel so down all the time."
 "It sounds like you're feeling pretty helpless and hopeless right now. Can you tell me more about why you feel like you're not good enough?"
 "I don't know, it's just a feeling I have. I see other people succeeding and it feels like they have it all together while I'm just flailing. It feels like no matter what I do, it's never going to be good enough."
 "It sounds like you're comparing yourself to others a lot and that's leading to feeling down about yourself. Comparison is tough because we can always find someone who seems to have it better than us, but that doesn't mean that we are bad people or that we will never succeed. Everyone has their own journey in life and yours is just as valuable as anyone else's. What matters is how you live your life and what you put your focus on. If you focus on all the ways you aren't measuring up, then of course you're going to feel bad about yourself. But if you focus on your own journey and your own successes, then you'll start to feel better about yourself."
 "Yeah, I guess that makes sense. It's just hard when everyone around me seems to be doing so well while I'm struggling so much."
 'It can be hard to watch others succeed while we are struggling, but we have to remember that everyone has their own journey in life and their own challenges to face. Just because someone else appears to be doing well doesn\'t mean they don\'t have struggles of their own behind the scenes. And even if they are doing well, that doesn\'t take away from your own worth or success in life."']

head: PersonX completes probation
tail: to move on with his life
literal: Noelani completes probation because Noelani wants to move on with his life.
narrative: Noelani was put on probation for drug possession. He was required to complete regular drug tests, attend counseling sessions, and perform community service. He has successfully completed his probationary period and is now able to move on with his life.
dialogue:
["Hey, officer. How's it going?" 'Not too bad. How about you?'
 "I'm doing alright. Just happy to have completed my probationary period successfully."
 "That's great! We're really proud of you and all the progress you've made."
 "Thanks. It was definitely a challenge at times, but I'm glad it's over now."
 'So what are your plans for the future?'
 "I'm not really sure yet. I just know that I want to stay out of trouble and stay clean."
 "That's a good goal to have. We'll be here to support you every step of the way."]

head: PersonX completed graduate school
literal: Nadira completed graduate school because Nadira wants to get a degree.
narrative: Nadira completed graduate school because she wants to get a degree in counseling. She feels that this will give her the tools she needs to help people who are struggling with similar issues that she has faced in her own life.
dialogue:
["I've been thinking a lot about what I want to do after I graduate, and I've decided that I want to become a counselor."
 "That's a great decision! Counseling can be a very rewarding career. What made you decide that you want to pursue this field?"
 "Well, there are a few reasons. First of all, I feel like I have a lot of personal experience with the kinds of issues that people who need counseling might be facing. And secondly, I really want to help people. I feel like counseling could be a way for me to make a difference in people's lives."
 'Those are both excellent reasons for wanting to become a counselor. Do you have any idea what type of counseling you would like to do? There are many different specialties within the field of counseling.'
 "Yeah, I've been doing some research on that, and I'm not really sure yet. There are so many options! But I think I would either like to work with children or with families."
 'That makes sense given your interests and experiences. Have you started looking into programs yet? There are several good counseling programs available at universities across the country.'
 "Yeah, I've started looking into a few of them. But I'm not sure which one is the right fit for me. I want to make sure that I choose a program that will give me the best education and prepare me for my career."
 "That's a great attitude! There are definitely many factors to consider when choosing a counseling program. Do you have any questions that you would like help with in making your decision?"
 "Yes, actually, I do have some questions. I was wondering if you could tell me more about accreditation and why it's important?"
 'Absolutely! Accreditation is important because it ensures that the counseling program meets certain standards set by the profession. This means that the program has been reviewed and approved by other professionals in the field. It also means that the program will likely provide you with a good education and prepare you well for your career as a counselor.'
 'That makes sense. Thank you for explaining it to me. Do you have any other advice on choosing a counseling program?'
 "Well, another thing to consider is whether you want to attend a brick-and-mortar school or an online school. There are advantages and disadvantages to both options. For example, brick-and-mortar schools typically offer more personal interaction between students and faculty, while online schools may be more flexible in terms of schedule and location. Ultimately, it's up to you to decide what type of environment you learn best in and what will work better for your lifestyle."
 'That\'s helpful, thank you! I\'ll definitely keep that in mind as I continue my research."']

head: PersonX finds hope and self-esteem in counseling
literal: Waylon finds hope and self-esteem in counseling because Waylon wants to be a better person.
narrative: Waylon finds hope and self-esteem in counseling because Waylon wants to be a better person. Waylon was dealing with a lot of personal issues and felt like counseling could help. After meeting with a counselor, Waylon felt more hopeful and had a better sense of self-esteem.
dialogue:
["I'm just not sure if I'm doing the right things. I want to be a good person, but sometimes I feel like I'm not doing enough."
 'Well, what do you think being a good person entails?'
 "Being honest, being kind, being helpful…I don't know, there's just so much. And sometimes I feel like I'm falling short."
 "It sounds like you have pretty high standards for yourself. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but it can be tough to always meet those standards. Do you think that might be part of the reason why you're feeling down lately?"
 'Yeah, maybe. I just feel like I could be doing more.'
 'What do you think would happen if you let go of some of those high standards and gave yourself a little bit of grace?'
 "I don't know…I guess it would make me feel better about myself? But then again, maybe that's just making excuses for myself."
 "There's no right or wrong answer here, Waylon. Ultimately, it's up to you to decide what feels best for you. If letting go of some of your standards makes you feel better about yourself and helps you to enjoy your life more, then that may be something worth considering."]

head: PersonX suggests seeking counseling
literal: Denzell suggests seeking counseling because Denzell wants to solve a problem.
narrative: Denzell's friend Sarah is going through a tough time. Denzell suggests that Sarah seek counseling to help her get through it.
dialogue:
["You've been going through a lot lately. I think it might help to talk to a counselor."
 "I don't know. I'm not sure if it would help."
 "It couldn't hurt, and it might give you some tools to deal with what's going on."
 "But what if they can't help me? What if they just make things worse?"
 "Sarah, they're professionals. They're trained to help people in your situation."
 "But what if they can't?"
 "Sarah, please give counseling a try. It's helped me in the past, and I really think it could help you too."]

head: PersonX agrees to seeing a counselor
literal: Jocelynn is mature. Jocelynn agrees to seeing a counselor.
narrative: Jocelynn is 26 years old and has agreed to see a counselor. He has been struggling with anxiety and depression for a few years and feels like he's at his wit's end. He's hoping that counseling will help him learn how to cope with his mental health issues in a more constructive way.
dialogue:
['Hey, thanks for seeing me.' 'Of course. How are you doing today?'
 "I'm alright, I guess. Just feeling a little down lately."
 "That's understandable. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?"
 "Yeah, it's just been really tough lately. I've been struggling with anxiety and depression for a few years now, and I feel like I'm at my wit's end. Nothing seems to be helping and I'm just really struggling to cope."
 "That sounds very difficult. It sounds like you're feeling pretty hopeless right now."
 "Yeah, I am. I don't know what to do anymore. I've tried medication and therapy, but nothing seems to be working."
 'Well, Jocelynn, first of all, it\'s important to remember that you\'re not alone in this- there are millions of people who struggle with mental health issues every day. And secondly, it sounds like you\'ve already tried a lot of different things to try and cope with your mental health issues- which is really commendable- but sometimes it takes trying a few different things before finding something that works for you personally. So don\'t give up hope yet- let\'s keep exploring different options and see if we can find something that works for you specifically."'
 "Alright, that makes sense. I'm just really tired of struggling all the time. It feels like every day is a battle."
 'Yes, I can imagine that it does. But remember, you\'re not alone in this fight- we\'re here to help you every step of the way. Let\'s continue to explore different options and find something that works for you."']

head: PersonX and PersonY start off right
literal: Brinleigh and Saraya start off right. Now Brinleigh wants to do the right thing.
narrative: Brinleigh and Saraya had been dating for a year when they decided to get married. They both wanted to do the right thing, so they started looking into pre-marital counseling. They found a great counselor who helped them work through some of their issues and learn more about each other.
dialogue:
['Hi Saraya, thanks for coming with me to counseling today.'
 "Hi Brinleigh. Yeah, I'm really looking forward to getting started."
 "Me too. Our counselor is really great and I think she'll help us a lot."
 'Yeah, I hope so. It would be nice to learn more about each other and work through some of our issues before we get married.'
 'Absolutely. So what do you want to talk about first?'
 'Well, I was thinking maybe we could start with family history? What were your childhoods like?'
 "That's a great idea. Let's see, where should I start...I was born in New York City and grew up on the Upper West Side. My parents are both doctors and they always expected me to follow in their footsteps. But I never really liked the idea of being a doctor...I was always more interested in art and design. So after college, I moved out here to Los Angeles to pursue a career in graphic design. As for my childhood, it was pretty typical, I guess...lots of school and extracurricular activities. What about you? Where did you grow up?"
 "I grew up in a small town in Michigan. It was a really close-knit community and everyone knew each other. I loved it there. After high school, I went to college for a year, but then I dropped out and moved to New York City. I've always been interested in fashion and I wanted to pursue a career in fashion design. So that's what I did...I started working as a assistant designer at a clothing company. And that's how I met you...you were one of my clients."
 "Yeah, that's right. Small world, huh?"
 "Yeah, it is. So what do you think about our families? Do you think they'll get along?"
 "My family is pretty easygoing, so I think they'll like yours just fine. Your family seems nice too. Hopefully they'll be okay with the fact that we're getting married so quickly..."
 "Yeah, my mom was a little surprised when I told her we were getting married so soon, but she's happy for us. She likes you a lot."
 "That's good to hear. So what do you think our wedding should be like? Big or small?"
 "Hmmm, tough question...I've always wanted a big wedding, but maybe something smaller would be more intimate and special. What do you think?"
 "Well, we can definitely afford a bigger wedding if that's what you want...but maybe something smaller would be nicer since it would be more personal and less stressf"]

head: PersonX begins a counseling session
literal: Abe begins a counseling session. Now Abe wants to be a counselor.
narrative: Abe has completed all the necessary education and requirements to become a counselor and has started seeing clients in his home office. Today is the first day of counseling sessions for Abe and he is feeling both excited and nervous to get started helping people in this way.
dialogue:
["Hello, my name is Abe and I'll be your counselor today."
 "Hi, Abe. I'm really nervous about this."
 "That's perfectly normal. Can you tell me your name?" "It's Sarah."
 "Nice to meet you, Sarah. Why don't we start by telling me what brings you here today?"
 "I've been really struggling lately. I just can't seem to make myself happy no matter what I do."
 'That sounds very difficult. Can you tell me more about that?'
 "It's like, no matter what I do, nothing makes me happy anymore. Everything I used to enjoy doesn't bring me the same happiness it used to."
 'That sounds very discouraging. Have you been experiencing this for a while?'
 "Yeah, it's been a few months now."
 "Sarah, based on what you've said, it sounds like you might be experiencing depression. Depression is a very common condition that can be extremely debilitating if left untreated. But there is hope and treatment available that can help you feel better again."
 "Really? There's something that can be done?"
 'Absolutely. Depression is treatable with medication and/or therapy. I think it would be beneficial for you to see a psychiatrist to discuss your options for medication and then we could also work together in therapy to address some of the underlying causes of your depression and help you learn how to cope with it in a healthy way.'
 "That sounds like it could really help. I'm willing to try anything at this point."
 "That's great! I'll give you some referrals for psychiatrists in the area and we'll get started in our sessions next week"]

head: PersonX is given counseling
literal: Elio is given counseling. Now Elio feels happy.
narrative: Elio goes to counseling sessions and starts to feel better. Elio is happy and relieved that they can talk about their feelings openly without judgement.
dialogue:
["I'm really glad we started these sessions. I feel like I can finally talk about my feelings without being judged."
 "That's great to hear, Elio. How have things been going since we last spoke?"
 "Actually, pretty good. I've been spending more time with my friends and doing things that make me happy. I feel like I'm slowly starting to heal from everything that happened."
 "That's terrific! It sounds like you're really making progress. Do you think you'll be ready to talk about what happened soon?"
 "Yeah, I think so. It's still hard to think about, but I know it's something I need to do."
 "We can take our time with it, but whenever you're ready, we'll be here for you."
 'Thank you. Just knowing that I have someone to talk to who understands me makes a big difference.'
 "I'm glad we can be here for you, Elio."]

head: PersonX really appreciates seeing a counselor
literal: Rustin really appreciates seeing a counselor. Now Rustin feels cared for.
narrative: Rustin has been struggling with anxiety and depression for years, but never felt comfortable enough to seek help. After finally opening up to a close friend about his struggles, they encouraged him to seek counseling. Rustin found an amazing counselor who he feels really connected to and has started making progress in managing his mental health.
dialogue:
['Hey there. Thanks for meeting with me today.'
 'Of course, thank you for coming in. How are you doing today?'
 "I'm feeling pretty good today, actually. I've been feeling a lot better lately thanks to your help."
 "That's great to hear! Can you tell me more about what's been going on that's helped you feel better?"
 "Yeah, definitely. I think just being able to talk to someone about what's going on has been really helpful. And also just learning some new coping strategies and techniques from you has made a big difference too. Just feeling like I have some tools to deal with my anxiety and depression has been really empowering."
 "That sounds like great progress! It sounds like you're really starting to make some positive changes in your life. Keep up the good work!"]

head: PersonX finds closure
literal: Graeson finds closure. Now Graeson feels at peace.
narrative: Graeson was in a car accident that killed his best friend. He was never able to forgive himself for it, but after years of therapy and grief counseling, he has finally been able to let go of the guilt and move on with his life.
dialogue:
["I'm sorry, I know I've talked about this a lot in therapy, but I just can't seem to shake this feeling of guilt. I keep thinking about my friend who died in the accident, and how it was all my fault."
 "Graeson, you've been through a lot of counseling and therapy over the years since the accident. You've done a lot of work on forgiving yourself and moving on. What do you think is holding you back from letting go of the guilt completely?"
 "I guess I just feel like I don't deserve to be forgiven. Like, how can I move on when my friend is dead because of me? It doesn't seem fair."
 "It's understandable that you would feel that way, but ultimately it's up to you whether or not you want to forgive yourself. If you're not ready yet, that's okay. But if you're finding that the guilt is impacting your daily life, it might be worth considering letting go of it so that you can live more fully in the present."
 "Yeah, I guess you're right. It's just, every time I think about it, I relive that moment when the accident happened and I see my friend's body being thrown from the car. I can't seem to forget it."
 "That's understandable. Those kinds of memories can be very powerful and hard to shake. But try to focus on the progress you've made since then. You were able to get through that tough time and you're still here, despite everything. That's something to be proud of."
 "Yeah, I guess you're right. Thank you for helping me see that."
 'Of course, Graeson. Anytime.']

head: PersonX enters counseling
literal: Rocio enters counseling. Now Rocio feels safe.
narrative: Rocio enters counseling. She meets with her counselor once a week to talk about her anxiety and depression. Rocio feels safe talking to her counselor about her feelings and she is slowly starting to feel better.
dialogue:
['Hi, counselor. Thanks for seeing me today.'
 'Hi, Rocio. How are you doing?'
 "I'm doing alright. I'm feeling a little better today, but still struggling with some anxiety and depression."
 "That's understandable. Can you tell me more about what's going on?"
 "Yeah. I've been having a lot of intrusive thoughts lately and my anxiety has been really bad. I'm also feeling really down and hopeless. I don't know why this is happening or how to make it stop."
 'It sounds like you\'re going through a lot right now. intrusive thoughts can be very difficult to deal with, as well as the anxiety and depression. But it sounds like you\'re working hard to try to understand what\'s going on and how to make it better. You\'re here seeking help, which is a great first step. Let\'s see if we can work on some of these issues together and see if we can help you feel better."'
 'Thank you, counselor. I appreciate your help.'
 "You're welcome, Rocio. Let's get started."]

head: PersonX’s marriage improves
literal: Roisin’s marriage improves. Now Roisin feels hopeful.
narrative: Roisin's marriage improved after he and his wife started attending counseling together. They began communicating better and working through their problems. Roisin feels hopeful that things will continue to get better between them.
dialogue:
['Hey, I wanted to talk to you about something.' 'What is it?'
 'I was thinking maybe we should start going to counseling together.'
 'Why do you think that?'
 'Well, things have been kind of tough between us lately and I think it would help us communicate better and work through our problems.'
 "I don't know...I'm not sure if I'm ready to open up like that."
 "It's okay, honey. I understand. But I really think it could help us. Plus, it's confidential so whatever we discuss will stay between us and the counselor."
 "Alright, let's give it a try then."
 "Great! I'll make an appointment and we'll go from there." 'Okay.']

head: PersonX receives counseling
literal: Jakhi receives counseling because Jakhi wants to be more confident.
narrative: Jakhi is seeking counseling to help with her confidence. She wants to be able to speak up more, and feel better about herself in social situations. She hopes that counseling will give her the tools she needs to make these changes.
dialogue:
["I don't know, I just feel so lost lately. I don't know how to fix it."
 "It sounds like you're feeling pretty down about yourself. Do you want to talk about what's going on?"
 "Yeah, I guess so. It's just, ever since I was a kid, I've always felt like I didn't quite fit in. Like there was something wrong with me that other people could see. And it's only gotten worse as I've gotten older. Now I can't even leave the house without having a panic attack."
 'That sounds really tough, Jakhi. Can you tell me more about why you feel this way? Do you think it has anything to do with your childhood?'
 "Yeah, I think so. My parents were always really hard on me and never seemed happy with anything I did. They would always compare me to my brothers and tell me how much better they were than me. And no matter what I did, it never seemed good enough for them. So I guess over time, I started to believe that maybe they were right...that there was something wrong with me and that's why nobody else wanted to be around me either."
 "Jakhi, first of all, let me say that there is nothing wrong with you. You are perfectly fine the way you are. Secondly, your parents' words might have hurt you more than they intended because they likely came from a place of their own insecurity and anxiety instead of truly reflecting how they felt about you as a person separate from your brothers..Lastly, let's work on building up your self-esteem by practicing some positive self-talk exercises together, okay?"]

head: PersonX discusses alternatives
tail: to be willing to discuss alternatives
literal: Alexia was willing to discuss alternatives. Alexia discusses alternatives.
narrative: Alexia was willing to discuss alternatives. He said that he would be willing to try a different approach if it would make his wife happy. He suggested that they could try couple's therapy or counseling.
dialogue:
["I'm willing to try a different approach if it would make you happy."
 'What do you mean?'
 "I mean, if there's something that you want me to do differently, I'll try it."
 'Well, I think we should go to counseling.' 'Okay.'
 'I think it would be good for us to talk to someone together about our relationship.'
 'I agree.']

head: PersonX begins a counseling session
literal: Golda begins a counseling session. Now Golda is encouraged to continue.
narrative: Golda begins a counseling session by telling the counselor his name and age. The counselor asks Golda how he is doing today. Golda responds that he is feeling okay, but has been having a lot of anxiety lately.
dialogue:
["It's been tough lately. I've been feeling really anxious and stressed out. I'm not sure what to do or where to turn."
 'Thank you for sharing that with me, Golda. Can you tell me more about what has been going on that has caused you to feel this way?'
 "Well, lately I've just been feeling really down and helpless. Everything seems so overwhelming and I don't know how to cope. I feel like I'm just spinning my wheels and getting nowhere."
 'That sounds very difficult. It sounds like you are feeling stuck in a rut right now. Have you been able to identify any specific triggers or situations that have contributed to your anxiety?'
 "Yeah, I think part of it is just feeling like I'm not in control of my life. My job is really demanding and I'm just constantly under a lot of pressure. I feel like I'm just treading water and trying to keep my head above water, but I'm never really making any progress."
 "It sounds like your job is a major source of stress for you right now. Have you considered making any changes or taking any steps to reduce the amount of stress you're experiencing at work?"
 "Yeah, I've thought about looking for a new job, but that's really scary. And also, even if I found a new job, there's no guarantee that it would be any less stressful than my current one. So, I don't know...I feel like I'm kind of stuck."
 "Well, it sounds like you have given some thought to changing jobs, but you're hesitant because you're worried about the unknown. That's understandable. Can you think of anything else that might help reduce your anxiety levels?"
 "Yeah, I've been thinking about talking to my boss about maybe reducing my workload or changing my hours. But again, that's really scary because I don't want to seem like I can't handle the work or that I'm not committed to the company."
 "It sounds like you're worried about what others might think if you make a change at work. Have you talked to anyone else about how you're feeling?"
 "No, not really...I guess I've just been keeping it all to myself because I feel like nobody would understand what I'm going through or be able to help me anyway."
 "Golda, it sounds like you're feeling very isolated right now and that's contributing to your anxiety levels. It might be helpful for you to talk to someone who can understand what you're going through and offer some support. Would you be willing to talk with someone else about this?"
 "Yeah...I guess so...I mean, it can't hurt, right?"]

head: PersonX enters counseling
literal: Paxton enters counseling. Now Paxton feels supported.
narrative: Now that Paxton has started attending counseling sessions, she feels much more supported. In particular, she appreciates being able to openly discuss her anxieties and feelings with her counselor, who always listens attentively and offers valuable insights. As a result of this regular support, Paxton feels calmer and more capable of dealing with whatever challenges come her way.
dialogue:
["I'm really glad I started coming to counseling. It's been really helpful to have someone to talk to about all of this stuff."
 "I'm glad to hear that, Paxton. How have things been going since we last spoke?"
 "Well, I've been feeling a little better overall, but I'm still struggling with anxiety quite a bit. It's just hard for me to relax and feel like everything is going to be okay."
 "That makes sense. Can you tell me more about what you're anxious about specifically?"
 "I guess I'm just worried about the future in general. I don't know what's going to happen or how things are going to turn out, and it's scary not having any control over it."
 'Yes, that can be very frightening. But one thing you can control is how you respond to your anxiety. For example, instead of letting it take over your thoughts and emotions, you can choose to focus on something else, like positive affirmations or breathing exercises. Just remember that you are strong and capable of handling whatever comes your way.'
 'Thank you for reminding me of that. Just knowing that I have some control over my anxiety makes me feel a little better already.']

head: PersonX goes back to counseling
literal: Carys was going to counseling. Carys goes back to counseling.
narrative: Carys is going to counseling. She has been going for a few months and it has been helping her deal with her anxiety. She goes back tomorrow for another session.
dialogue:
["I'm feeling really anxious about my upcoming session tomorrow. I'm not sure what to expect or what we'll talk about."
 "It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure and have some worries about tomorrow's session. Let's explore those feelings a bit and see if we can't ease some of that anxiety. What specifically are you worried about? Is it the unknown, or is there something specific that's worrying you?"
 "I guess I'm just worried about what we'll talk about. I'm not sure if I'm ready to talk about some of the things that have been on my mind lately."
 "That's understandable. It can be tough to open up and share our innermost thoughts and feelings, especially when we're feeling vulnerable. But remember, you're in control of the conversation. If there's something you're not comfortable discussing, you can always say so. We can talk about whatever you'd like tomorrow, but maybe this is something we can touch on next time?"
 'Yeah, that sounds good. Thanks for understanding.'
 'Of course, Carys. See you tomorrow.']

head: PersonX receives counseling
tail: to be in control of his life
literal: Lucus receives counseling because Lucus wants to be in control of his life.
narrative: Lucus, a college student, is having trouble in school and decides to seek out counseling. She meets with her counselor weekly to discuss her goals and progress. Through this process, Lucus begins to understand herself better and starts making positive changes in her life.
dialogue:
['Hi, thank you for meeting with me today.'
 'Of course, how are you doing?'
 "I've been better. I'm struggling a bit in school and I just feel really lost right now."
 "That sounds tough. Can you tell me more about what's going on?"
 "It's just that everything feels so overwhelming and I don't know where to start. I feel like I'm falling behind and I'm really stressed out all the time."
 'Do you want to talk about specific classes or assignments that are giving you trouble?'
 "Yeah, there's this one paper that's due soon and I have no idea what to write about. And then there's this test coming up that I'm really worried about too. Every time I sit down to study, my mind just goes blank and I can't focus at all. Sometimes it feels like everything is moving too fast and I can't keep up. Other times, it feels like everything is just happening in slow motion and nothing is getting done. It's so frustrating!"
 "It sounds like you're feeling really stuck right now. That's understandable given everything that you're dealing with. Let's see if we can brainstorm some ideas for how to get unstuck. Do you have any thoughts about what might help?"
 "I don't know, I just feel so lost. I don't even know where to start."
 'Well, one place we could start is by breaking down your paper into smaller tasks. For example, maybe you can start by brainstorming a list of possible topics to write about. Once you have a few ideas, you can then narrow it down to the one that you want to focus on. Then, you can begin doing some research and outlining your paper. Breaking it down into smaller steps like this might make it feel less overwhelming and more manageable.'
 "Yeah, that makes sense. I think I need to structure my time better too. I've been trying to study for hours at a time, but it's just not working out well for me."
 "Yes, it sounds like trying to study for long periods of time is actually causing more anxiety for you because you're not able to focus properly and retain information during those times anyway. So, in addition to breaking down your assignments into smaller tasks, maybe try setting shorter study periods for yourself as well. For example, instead of studying for three hours straight, maybe try studying for 30 minutes and then taking a 10-minute break in between each session. See if that works better for you in terms of being able to focus and retaining information better."
 'Yeah, that definitely sounds like it would be less stressful. I\'m going to try that next time I sit down to study then."']

head: PersonX enters counseling
literal: Leonidas is troubled. Leonidas enters counseling.

dialogue:
["I don't know, it's just hard. I've been here for a month and I still don't have any friends."
 'Why do you think that is?'
 "I don't know. Everyone seems to already have their groups and they're not interested in making new friends."
 'Have you tried reaching out to anyone?'
 "Yeah, I've tried talking to people but it feels like they're just not interested."
 "That must be really tough for you, feeling like you're the only one who is struggling to make friends."
 'Yeah, it is. I just feel so alone all the time and I hate it.'
 "Well, let's talk about some strategies for making friends then. What do you think might work?"]

head: PersonX hears a counselor on the radio
literal: Landrie hears a counselor on the radio. Now Landrie wants to go to counseling.
narrative: The counselor on the radio was talking about how counseling can help people with their problems. Landrie was interested in what the counselor had to say and decided that he wanted to try counseling.
dialogue:
["I'm struggling with some things in my life and I was wondering if counseling could help me out."
 'Absolutely! Counseling can be a great way to help people work through their problems. It can provide a safe space for you to explore your thoughts and feelings, and to learn more about yourself. Counseling can also help you develop new skills for dealing with difficult situations.'
 "That sounds really helpful! I'm not sure if I'm ready to talk about my problems with someone, but I'm willing to give it a try."
 "That's great! I encourage you to be as open and honest as you feel comfortable during our sessions. It might take some time for you to feel comfortable sharing everything, but that's okay. Just take your time and let me know if there's anything you're not comfortable discussing."
 "Alright, I'll try my best."
 "Great! I'm here to support you through whatever you need to talk about."]

head: PersonX hears a counselor on the radio
literal: Carlos hears a counselor on the radio. Now Carlos goes to counseling.
narrative: Carlos hears a counselor on the radio. The counselor is talking about how to deal with stress. Carlos decides to go to counseling.
dialogue:
['So, how do you deal with stress?'
 'One way to deal with stress is to figure out what is causing it. Once you know what is causing your stress, you can start to make a plan to address it.'
 "That makes sense. I've been feeling really stressed lately but I'm not sure why."
 "Well, let's explore that together. What has been going on in your life that might be causing you stress?"
 "I don't know. Everything just seems really overwhelming lately."
 'Can you give me some more specific examples?'
 "Well, school has been really tough and I'm worried about my grades. And my parents are always fighting and it's just really stressful at home."
 "It sounds like you have a lot on your plate. It's no wonder you're feeling stressed out! Let's see if we can come up with a plan to help you deal with all of this. Do you think that would be helpful?"]

head: PersonX decides to get help
literal: Marcellus is determined. Marcellus decides to get help.
narrative: Marcellus was determined to get help. He decided that he would go to the counseling center on campus. He made an appointment and went to his first session.
dialogue:
['Hi, thanks for seeing me.' 'Of course, what can I do for you?'
 "Well, it's hard to know where to start. I guess I've been feeling really down lately and I'm not sure why. Everything just feels so overwhelming and hopeless. I don't feel like myself anymore and I don't know how to fix it."
 "That sounds very difficult. Can you tell me more about how you've been feeling?"
 "Well, like I said, I just feel really down. I'm not interested in anything anymore and I just feel really hopeless. Everything feels so pointless."
 'That does sound very tough. Have you been having any suicidal thoughts?'
 "Yeah, I have actually. I've been thinking about it a lot lately and I'm just not sure how much longer I can keep going like this."
 "Okay, well first of all, it's important to know that you are not alone in feeling this way and that there is help available. Suicide is a permanent solution to a temporary problem and we want to do everything we can to help you through this difficult time. Let's talk about some coping strategies that might help you deal with these feelings."]

Jamyia said that she appreciated his willingness to talk and work on things, and she suggested counseling as a way to start working on their issues.
dialogue:
["I'm willing to do anything to make our marriage work. What do you think we can do to improve things?"
 'Counseling could be a good way to start working on our issues.'
 "I'm open to that. What do you think we should work on in counseling?"
 'I think we need to work on communication and trust.'
 "I agree. I'm sorry for not being more communicative in the past. I'll try to do better."
 'Thank you. I appreciate your willingness to try.']

head: PersonX goes back to counseling
tail: to improve her relationship with her mother
literal: Kaydance goes back to counseling because Kaydance wants to improve her relationship with her mother.
narrative: Kaydance goes back to counseling because she wants to improve her relationship with her mother. She has been attending counseling sessions for the past few months, but she feels like she's not making any progress. She hopes that by going back, she'll be able to finally make some headway.
dialogue:
["I feel like I'm not making any progress."
 "How do you feel like you're not making any progress?"
 "I don't know. It just feels like every time I try to talk to my mom, we just end up arguing. And then afterwards, I feel even worse than before."
 "It sounds like you're feeling really frustrated. Can you tell me more about that?"
 "Yeah, I guess I am. I just wish things could be different between us. We used to be so close, and now it feels like we're worlds apart. All she ever wants to talk about is how disappointed she is in me and how much of a screw-up I am. It's really hard to take sometimes."
 'That does sound difficult. Do you think there might be some underlying reasons why your relationship has changed so much?'
 'Like what?'
 'Well, have there been any major changes or events in your life recently that might have impacted your relationship with your mom?'
 'You mean besides the fact that I dropped out of college and moved back home? Yeah, that definitely didn\'t help things. But even before that, things were already pretty strained between us. She\'s always been a bit of a perfectionist and she\'s always had high expectations for me, but it seems like lately she\'s been even harder on me than usual. Nothing I do is ever good enough for her anymore. And now with me being back home and not doing anything with my life, she says it\'s just confirmed everything she always thought about me – that I\'m lazy and irresponsible and will never amount to anything." Kaydance pauses for a moment before continuing tearfully,"I just hate feeling like such a disappointment to her all the time."']

head: PersonX begins a counseling session
literal: Louie begins a counseling session. Now Louie feels open.
narrative: Louie began a counseling session by discussing her recent problems and how they had been affecting her. She felt that she could trust the counselor and feel comfortable discussing sensitive topics.
dialogue:
["I don't know what's wrong with me. I just can't seem to focus on anything or be happy anymore."
 "It sounds like you've been going through a tough time. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?"
 "I just feel like I'm stuck in this rut and I can't get out of it. Everything feels so pointless and I don't know how to make it better."
 "It sounds like you're feeling lost and helpless right now. But it's important to remember that you are not alone in this and there are people who care about you and want to help you through this tough time."
 "It's just so hard. I feel like I've tried everything and nothing works."
 "Well, sometimes it takes a while to find the right solution. But it's important to keep trying and to believe that things can get better. Do you have any ideas about what might help you feel better?"
 "I don't know. I just wish I could find some way to make all of this go away."
 "It sounds like you're feeling really overwhelmed right now. Maybe one thing we could work on is finding some ways to deal with stress and anxiety. There are lots of different techniques that can be helpful in managing these feelings. Would you be interested in learning more about some of these techniques?"]

head: PersonX needs counseling
literal: Shantel is depressed. Shantel needs counseling.
narrative: Shantel is depressed because she lost her job and her boyfriend left her. She is struggling to pay her bills and feels like she has no one to turn to. Shantel needs counseling to help her deal with her depression and get her life back on track.
dialogue:
["I just feel so lost right now. I don't know what to do or where to turn."
 "It sounds like you are going through a lot and feeling very overwhelmed. Depression can make it difficult to see hope or a way out of our current situation. Let's talk about some things that may help you feel better and give you some direction."
 "I don't know if anything can help me feel better at this point. I've lost my job, my boyfriend left me, and I'm struggling to pay my bills. I just feel like such a failure."
 'While it is understandable to feel down after experiencing all of these losses, it is important to remember that depression is not your fault and there is nothing wrong with seeking help. You are taking the first step by talking to me today. Can you tell me more about why you feel like a failure?'
 "I guess it just feels like everything in my life is falling apart and I can't seem to fix it. No matter what I do, things just keep getting worse. And now with the holidays coming up, it just feels like everything is so hopeless."
 "The holiday season can be tough for people who are struggling emotionally because it can be a reminder of all that we're missing in our lives or of past happy times that we're no longer experiencing. But again, it's important to remember that depression is not your fault and there is hope for feeling better again. What has helped you in the past when you've felt down? Is there anything you can do now to take care of yourself physically or emotionally?"
 'In the past, spending time with friends and family has really helped me when I\'ve felt down but right now everyone seems so busy with their own lives and I don\'t want to burden them with my problems. And as far as taking care of myself goes,I\'ve been trying to eat healthy and exercise but it\'s hard when I\'m feeling so low energy all the time. Just getting out of bed in the morning feels like such a struggle."']

 "I know. I want to try to work on our marriage. I don't want to lose you."
 "I don't want to lose you either. Counseling might help us communicate better."
 "I think that's a good idea." 'We should probably go soon.'
 "Yeah, I think that's a good idea."]

head: PersonX talks with a psychologist
literal: Denton talks with a psychologist. Now Denton feels depressed.
narrative: Denton spoke with a psychologist about theirdepression. The psychologist noted that Denton had been feeling down for a while and that they were struggling to find enjoyment in activities they used to enjoy. They advised Denton to seek counseling and medication if necessary, in order to help them cope with their depression.
dialogue:
["Yeah, I've been feeling down for a while now. I'm struggling to find enjoyment in activities I used to enjoy."
 'That sounds very difficult. What do you think might be causing your depression?'
 "I'm not really sure. I guess it could be a combination of things. My job is pretty stressful and I don't have much free time to do things I enjoy. Plus, my personal life isn't great either. I'm single and all my friends are in relationships or married with kids. It feels like everyone is moving on with their lives and leaving me behind."
 "It sounds like you're feeling isolated and like you're not where you want to be in life. That can definitely contribute to depression. Do you have anyone you can talk to about how you're feeling?"
 "No, not really. My family is out of town and my friends are busy with their own lives. Plus, I don't really want to burden them with my problems."
 "That's understandable, but it's important to have someone to talk to about what's going on with you. Is there anyone at work you can confide in?"
 "No, not really. We're all pretty busy and stressed out at work and nobody ever has time for small talk, let alone anything serious."
 'Well, it sounds like you\'re feeling pretty alone right now. Have you considered seeing a counselor or therapist? They can help provide support and guidance through difficult times like this. Medication may also be an option if your depression is severe enough."']

head: PersonX begins a counseling session
literal: Jayquan begins a counseling session. Now Jayquan is helped by the counselor.
narrative: Jayquan begins a counseling session. Jayquan tells the counselor that she is struggling with anxiety and feels like she can't cope with her daily life. The counselor listens to Jayquan and gives her some tips on how to manage her anxiety.
dialogue:
["I just feel so overwhelmed all the time. I can't even focus on anything anymore."
 "It sounds like you're really struggling with anxiety. Let's talk about some ways that we can help you manage that anxiety and get through your day-to-day life. One thing that might be helpful is to come up with a list of things that make you anxious and then brainstorming some coping strategies for each one. For example, if you're anxious about going to work, you might come up with a plan to get ready for work the night before so you're not rushed in the morning, or you might try deep breathing exercises before walking into your office."
 'That actually makes a lot of sense. I never really thought of it that way before.'
 "Another thing that can be helpful is to schedule in some relaxation time for yourself every day. This can be something as simple as taking a few minutes to read or take a bath. It's important to find something that works for you and that you enjoy so that it doesn't feel like another chore on your list. Taking care of yourself is essential in managing anxiety and stress."
 "Yeah, I definitely need to start doing more of that. I always feel guilty when I take time for myself because there's always something else I could be doing instead."
 "That's a common feeling, but it's important to remember that taking care of yourself is not selfish, it's necessary. You deserve to have some time each day where you can relax and recharge, even if it's just for 10 minutes"]

head: PersonX begins a counseling session
literal: Amyia begins a counseling session. Now Amyia feels anxious.
narrative: Amyia begins a counseling session. He feels nervous and unsure of what to expect. He fidgets with his hands and avoids making eye contact with the counselor.
dialogue:
["Hi. Thanks for seeing me today. I'm not really sure what to expect, but I guess I just need someone to talk to."
 "That's perfectly normal, Amyia. Why don't you start by telling me a little bit about why you're here?"
 "Well, I've been feeling really down lately. I'm not enjoying the things I used to and I just feel kind of lost. My grades have been slipping and I've been getting into arguments with my parents a lot. They just don't understand what it's like for me right now."
 "It sounds like you're going through a tough time. Can you tell me more about how you're feeling? Are you having any thoughts of harming yourself or others?"
 "No, nothing like that. I would never hurt myself or anyone else on purpose. It's just that everything feels so hard right now and sometimes I wonder if it's worth it to keep going."
 'Thank you for sharing that with me, Amyia. It sounds like you\'re feeling pretty hopeless right now. But it\'s important to remember that there is always hope, no matter how dark things seem at the moment. suicidal thoughts are very common during periods of depression, so please don\'t hesitate to reach out for help if those thoughts become too overwhelming or intense."']

head: PersonX's depression is severe

dialogue:
["I just don't know what to do. I feel like there's no point in anything anymore."
 "It sounds like you're feeling hopeless and helpless. Depression can make it hard to see any light at the end of the tunnel. But I want you to know that there is hope and we can work together to get you feeling better."
 "I don't know if I can believe that. Every day is just a struggle to get through. I don't see how things could ever get better."
 'One thing that might help is if we talk about some of your specific concerns and worries. That way we can develop a plan to address them head on.'
 "I'm just so tired all the time. It feels like such an effort to even get out of bed in the morning, let alone try to face the day ahead. And my appetite has really decreased lately so I've lost weight, which doesn't help how bad I feel about myself already."
 "Those are all valid concerns that we can certainly address as part of your treatment plan. For now, why don't we start by scheduling a follow-up appointment so we can continue this discussion?"]

head: PersonX applies to graduate school
literal: Luca applies to graduate school because Luca wants to pursue a career.

['Hi, Dr. Kestler. I wanted to talk to you about something important.'
 "Hi, Luca. What's up?"
 "I'm thinking about going back to school and getting my master's degree in counseling."
 "That's great! I think you would make an excellent counselor."
 "Thank you, I appreciate your support. I'm just not sure if it's the right time for me financially or if it's even possible with my work schedule."
 "Well, let's talk about it and see what we can figure out. Do you have any particular schools in mind?"
 "I'm not sure yet. I was hoping you might have some suggestions."
 "Let me see what I can find and get back to you. In the meantime, why don't you look into some scholarships or financial aid?"
 "That's a good idea. Thank you, Dr. Kestler."
 'Of course, Luca. Good luck with everything.']

head: PersonX suggests seeking counseling

["Hi, I'm Kimaya. What brings you in today?"
 "I'm not really sure. I just feel like something is off and I can't quite put my finger on it."
 "That sounds pretty common. A lot of people come in feeling that way. Why don't we start by talking about some of the things that have been going on in your life lately?"
 "Yeah, that makes sense. I guess things have just been really tough lately. My job is really stressful and I'm just not feeling very good about myself."
